div.p: THE FIRST PART OF A TREATISE CONCERNING POLICY, AND RELIGION.

Wherein the infirmitie of humane wit is amply declared, with the necessitie of Gods grace, and true Religion for the perfection of policy; And by the way some political matters are treated; Diuers principles of Macchiauel confuted; And many aduises geuen, tending no lesse to religious piety, then to true policy; With a confutation of the arguments of Atheists, against the prouidence of God, which is clearly proued throughout the whole.
Written by THOMAS FITZHERBERT Esquire, and Catholique priest, for the benefite of you • g Statists.
div.q: Sit homen Domini benedictum a seculo &c. The name of God be blessed for euer, and euer, for wisdome, and fortitude are his, and he changeth times, and ages, and transposeth, and ordaineth kingdomes at his pleasure. Dan. 2.

div.head: TO MY SONNE EDWARD FITZHERBERT.
div.p: KINDNES, saith the prouerbe, wil creepe where it can not goe; The meaning is, if I be not deceiued, that such is the force of loue and affection, that when it can not manifest it selfe so amply as it wold, it wil show it selfe in some sort as it may; the which is now verified in me; For, wheras I haue neuer hetherto had the meanes, & oportunity to manifest my affection towards you, by reason of my departure from you and my cuntry, in your infancy, & my continual absence euer since, (for the space of these three and twenty yeres) I can no longer forbeare to geue you some testimony of my loue, by the particular addresse of this treatise vnto you; For, although I intend it generally to al my cuntrymen, for the publyk good, yet I can not but wish the best part of the benefit to you, to whom the fruite of al my labours is most due, both by a special prerogatiue of nature, and also by the particular priuiledge of my owne desire, and your desert.

Therfore, to the end you may reape the benefit which I wish you of this treatise, you shal vnderstand, that although part of the subject is policy, yet my meaning is not to animat you to the study, or practise therof, for that in my many yeres trauel, & seruice of forrayne princes, (wherin I haue obserued the successe of many, great
negotiations, & bene my selfe emploied in some) I haue learned by experience, that the old prouerb, Of little medling commeth great ease, is verified in nothing more then in matters of state; the practise wherof may wel be compared to the vse of fire, which though it be most necessary for man, yet is most dangerous to deale with, and doth men some times irreparable dammages, be they neuer so circumspect. And this I say, for that I haue knowne very many stats-men of greate sufficiency, much perplexed, and diuers ruined, not so much by their owne inconsideration, as by the difficulties, and dangers incident to the handling of state-matters, which are subiect to infinit accidents, and hazards, impossible to be fore-seene and preuented, by the witt, or industry of man; And therfore the only point of state, which I wold haue you to learne, or at least to practise, is, to serue God and your prince, with al duty and loyalty, yeelding (as our Sauiour commandeth) To Caesar that vvhich is Caesars;
Matth. 22. and to God, that vvhich is Gods: And euer to perswade your selfe, that honesty ioyned with piety, & prudent simplicity, is the highest and surest policy that may be: for as Salomon saith; Qui ambulat simpliciter,
Pro. 10. ambulat confidenter, & qui deprauat vias suas manifestus erit. He vvhich vvalketh simply and plainly, vvalketh cōfidently & surely, & he that rūneth an vndirect course shal be made manifest. And this our Sauiour also taught his Apostles, Natth. 10. and vs al, when he said. Estote Prudentes sicut serpentes, & simplices sicut columba. Be you prudent like to the serpent, and simple like to the doue; whereof I shal not neede to say more vnto you here, for that I haue sufficiently hādled this matter in this treatise, in the which I wold wish you for your better instructiō, to obserue specially these points following.

The first is; The natural imbecillity of mans wit; the
consideration wherof is most necessary for euery man, to • he end he may not only beware of presumption, and an • uer-weening of his owne wit (the danger wherof I haue • eclared in the first, and second Chapter) but also haue • ecourse to the remedies which God hath ordained for • ans infirmity; that is to say, continual praier to him for • he light and helpe of his grace, and the councel of discreete, and wise frends; of both which points I haue trea
• ed at large, partlie in the 28. Chapter, and partly in my • ules for young statists; wherto I remit you.

The second obseruation which I wish you to make, is, of the course of Gods prouidence in the affaires of men, • s how he disposeth not only of kingdomes and states, but • lso of particular mens affaires, working his wil in them, • nd by them, some times manifestlie, and some times • y secret operation, permitting euil to the end to draw good therof, and seruing him selfe of mens wills, wits, • olicies, and power, as also of al other his creatures, • nd of al manner of causes, natural, moral, and ac
• idental, for the execution of his holly wil, and secret • udgements; The consideration wherof infinitely im
• orteth euery Christian man, as wel for the discharge of • is dutie towards God, as also for his owne special come
• ort, throughout the whole course of his life.

For he that alwaise hath the prouidence of God before • is eyes, and acknowledgeth his merciful disposition in what soeuer befalleth him, is neither puffed vp with pride 〈◊〉 prosperity, nor deiected with sorrow in aduersity, nor • et dismayed with the apprehention of dangers, but alwaise holdeth an euen and stedfast course, resigned to Gods wil, grateful for his benefits, not repining at his • unishments, knowing that al wil turne to his good, if the • ault be not in him selfe; whereby the seruants of God
receiue infinit cōsolation, wheras those who haue not the like consideration of Gods prouidence, haue neither any stay of them selues in prosperity, nor any true comfort in aduersity, but being no lesse dissolute in the one, then desperate in the other, perish many tymes in both, through Gods iust Iudgement. And although you shal find matter considerable concerning this poynt, throughout this whole discourse, yet I specially recommende two Chapters to your reading, to wit the 25. and 26. where I haue declared the causes why God permitteth good men to be afflicted, and wicked men to prosper in this world, which being wel waied may yeeld you, as I hope, both consolation, and instruction.

The third poynt to be obserued is, the seuere Iustice of God in the punishment of sinne, Exod. 20. (Visiting the iniquityes of parents vpon the children vnto the 3. and 4. generation) which as I haue made most euident in princes, and their states, so may it also be obserued in priuate men, and particular families. Therfore the instruction, which I wold wish you to take by this point, is, that the true cause of the decay and ouerthrow of most families, is the same that I haue showed by euident examples to be the ruin of kingdomes, & states, to wit the sinnes of men, punished eyther in them selues, or in their children and posterity, wherby whole families are extirped, races extinguished, ancient houses decaied, and personnal defects, or imperfections, continued sometimes in families for many decents.

Wherby it may appeare, how simple they are, who hope to eternize their names and families, by wicked meanes, and how absurdly many men vse to saye, that he is happy whose father goeth to the deuil (because wicked men leaue many times their children rich, with il gotten goods) whereas experience teacheth, that although God of his
secret Iudgements suffreth euil men to prosper for a while for such causes as I haue signified in the 26. Chapter) yet • e punisheth them, and dissipateth their ill gathered sub
• ance sooner or later, wher vpon groweth the prouerbe:
• ale parta, male dilabuntur; Goods il gotten, are il spent. Et vix • udebit tertius haeres; And they seeldome descend to the third • neratiō. VVherfore we may say with far more reason, that • e is vnhappy whose parents sinnes may drawe the male
• ction, & wrath of God vpon him; and that most happy he, who fearing God, and being descended of vertuous • arents, enheriteth not only their wel gotten goods, but • lso Gods blessing for their vertues; For such a one hath a • sting stock, and an indeficient treasure, yeelding an as
• red fruite to him, & his; which I wish you alwayse to re
• ember, to the end you may liue in the feare of God, • at it may please him to blesse you with his grace, and al • mporal happines, yea and to prosper, and perpetuate • our posterity, for his owne glory, and the good of your • untry; For, Sic benedicetur qui timet Dominum;
Psal. 127. So shal he be • lessed who feareth God.

Furdermore you shal find in this treatise diuers political recepts, and rules, which though as I said before, I doe • ot aduise you to practise, yet it can not hurt you to know, • nd the rather for that many of them may be applyed to • e condicion, or state of any particular man; such being • e connexion of al the parts of prudence, (wherof po
• cy is one) that they concurre, and communicate in many • ings, in so much that an aduise may be very political, • r good for the administration of state, and withal very econnomical, or fit for the gouernment of houshold, yea • nd necessary for the direction of any priuat man, in his • articular affaires; of which kinde, diuers wil occurre • nto you, in reading this treatise.

In like manner, whereas I haue interlaced many thing • against Atheists, which you, and other good Christians, may perhaps omit to reade, as not pertaining any way to you, I think good to aduertise you, that you may also find therin matter woorth your consideration, for that I haue by the occasion of their obiections, cleared diuers douts, explicated many difficultyes, & decyded some notable questions; which may serue, not only for the confirmation of our Christian fayth, but also for the edification of any good Christian reader, yea and stirre him vp to the admiration of Gods infinite wisdome, iustice, mercy bounty, & omnipotent power, and to the due reuerence, and feare of his inscrutable Iudgements.

Moreouer, hauing had desire both to delight, & profit my readers, I haue sowed in this my gardain (as I may tearme it) the seede as wel of moral, as of political doctrin, and haue watered it aboundantly with al kind of history, yea more perhaps then wil seeme conuenient to some curious and seuere censurers, who may desire to haue al things restrained to the limits of their lyking; Neuerthelesse, I wold haue such to vnderstand if any such there be that I haue bene the more copious in examples, for the better and more cleare confutation of Macchiauillian, & Atheistical politikes, who referring al the effects of Gods secret Iudgements, yea and of many of their owne errours to chance, are best conuinced by experience, which is cheefely deduced from history, and showed best by multitudes of examples.

Therfore I wold haue you to think that I inuite you to the reading of this treatise, as to a gardain, in the which I hope you shal find variety of faire flowers, and holsome hearbs; wherof I wish you first to take a ful view, & after to make your selfe a nosegay of what you like best, for I
can not expect that you, or any other, wil like and allow, • f euery thing alike, which I treate, or teach in this Treatise, no more then it can be expected, that many guests in
• ited to a feast, be it neuer so wel furnished, shalbe al of • hem contented alike with euery dish: and therfore euen • s many dishes are prouided, not so much that al the guests • ay eate of euery one, as that euery guest may haue some • ish to his liking; euen so I haue proposed to my readers • ariety of matter in this discourse, not so much hoping • hat al of them wil be pleased with euery thing therin, as • hat euery one of them may find some thing to content him

To conclude; I wold not haue you expect in this my Treatise, any curiosity of exquisit words, or fine filed phra
• es, or other ornaments of eloquence, because nether my declining yeares, (where with my stile is also declined) neither yet the grauity of the matter which I handle, doe seeme to me to permit any other then a plaine stile, and familiar manner of writing, accommodated to common capacity for the publike good; Besides that I perceiue by such english bookes, as I haue chanced to see, printed in England of late, that the english tongue is much altered since I came thence, and therfore I may wel feare, that the language currant in my time (which I am forst to vse because I neuer vsed, nor learned other) may now seeme no lesse barbarous to some men, then diuers new woords, • nd phrases seeme strange to me; But howsoeuer it be, I hope my louing, and courteous cuntrimen, wil measure this my woork rather by the matter, and my good meaning, then by the language, or manner of composition, and that for supplement of al defects, they wil accept the abundance of my good wil, and desire of their benefit, which hath moued me to take this paines, to treate of a
necessary subiect, neuer handled before in our tongue, fo • ought I know; In which respect I hope it may be the more grateful vnto them; And this being al which I haue thought needful to aduertise you touching the Treatise following, I referre you to the preface for your further satisfaction, concerning my further intention, as wel in this first part, as in the second, which by Gods grace shal follow in tyme, if God geue me lyfe and health; And in the meane whyle, I wish you al contentment, and the abundance of Gods grace, taking my leaue with this benediction of the Psalmist. Benedicat tibi Dominus ex Sion, & videas bona Hierusalem omnibus diebus vitae tuae, & videas filios filiorum tuorum, pacem super Israel.

div.head: THE PREFACE, VVHERE IN IT IS SIGNIFIED VVHO ARE POLITIKS; Hovv they erre in Religion; and vvhat difference there is betvvixt them and other heretykes; Also vvhat is the intention of the Author in this Treatise, and in the other part therof that is to follovve; And lastly some foundations are layed for the proofe of Gods prouidence in humaine affaires.
div.p:
AMONGST many errors concerning Religion which are currant in this our vnfortunate age, none is more dangerous or pernitious then the opinion of such, as are commonly called Politikes; so named, not because they practize true and perfect policie, but because they esteeme them selues, or are of many falsly repu
• ed, for prudent and politike men: and therfore as the Latin word Tirannus which at first did signify a monarche,Calepin Varro. & alij. and absolute • inge, came afterwardes by the abuse of roial authority to signi
• y only a Tyrant, and as in like manner the word Latrones signified • t the first such as were the guards of princes, and grew in time • y their disloyalty to be vnderstood of Robbers, & theeues;VVhat the name of politike signifieth properly. VVhat policy is. so al
• o though the name of a Politike doth signify in deede such a one • s practiseth that parte of humaine prudence which concerneth • tate, and is properly called Policy, yet by the abuse of such as pro
• esse the same, it beginneth in al languages to be taken in euil • arte, and is commonly applyed only to those,The name of a politike commonly taken in euil part and of vvhom it is vnderstood. Politiks peruert the order of nature. who framinge a • olicy after their owne fancy, no lesse repugnant to reason, then • o conscience & religion, change al the course of true wisdome • nd prudence, and peruert the order of nature it selfe, preferring • hinges lesse worthy, before the more worthy, inferiour thinges • efore superiour, corporal before spiritual, temporal before • ternal, humane before deuine, the body before the soule, earth • efore heauen, and the world before God.

Hovv & vvhen politikes ar heretiks in the highest degree.2. Therefore whereas these politikes erre no lesse in religio • then in polycie, they also deserue the name of heretickes, and are so indeede in the highest degree, when obstinacy concurreth with their error. For others which teach false doctrine in matter of religion,The difference in matter of religion betvvixt politiks & other heretiks. doe erre only in some parte of the Catholike faith but politickes erre in the whole. Heretikes either impugne our Sauiour Christ, or his Saintes, or his spowse the Churche, or some parson of the blessed Trinitie, but politikes make warre against al these, yea against Deitye it selfe. Heretikes admitting some groundes of Christian faith, doe denye and deride the rest; but politikes seeming to admit al, doe in deede deny, contemne, and deride al. Heretikes though they reiect some parte of true religion, yet they haue some religion; but politikes admittinge in shew al religions, haue in truth no religion, denying either God him selfe, or at lest his prouidence in the affaires of men, which is the ground of al religion. Finally heretykes vndermine and shake the foundations of Christiani • y,Politiks ouerthrovv the foundations of Christianity. but politikes doe vtterly ouerthrow it; for although they graunt, and acknowledge the necessity of religion, aswel to the institution, as also for the administration, and conseruation of commonwealth, yet they so litle consider the nature, dignity, and true effectes therof, that they preferre in al thinges, reason of state before reason of religion, as though religion were ordained only for the seruice of commonwealth; Yea, and which is more to be lamented,Hovv politiks abuse religion. they vse it no otherwise then as nurses vse fables of bug-beares to terrify litle children withal, to make them the more obedient; as though religion or beleefe of a God, were only a matter of opinion, consisting in phantasy, and imagination, and deuised to keepe men in awe, & feare of eternal punishment, to make them the more obedient to temporal lawes; in which respect those which holde this opinion care not greatly what religion be professed, so that the people perswade them selues that there is some God which punisheth euil men, and rewardeth the good, whereby they doe not only ouerthrowe al religion, but also vtterly destroy and ruyne in tyme, the kingdomes & commonwelthes where they gouerne, as shal euidently appeare in this Treatise.

3. And whereas it seemeth to me that this error proceedeth
principally of two causes, the one;VVhence the error of politike proceedeth. for that many men haue so • reat a presumption of their owne wisdome, that they measure • herby al thinges, as wel deuine as humaine; and the other for •• at they know not, or at least,This treatise deuided into 2. parts. doe not duely consider the na
•• re, force, fruit, and dignity of true religion in Commonwelth; wil therefore deuide this Treatise in to two partes.

4. In the first, I wil shew the insufficiency of mans wit, po
• cy, and power, for the institution,The contents of the first part. gouernment and conserua
• ion of common wealth, with out the peculiar help & assistance • f Gods grace, which can not be had with out true religion. • n the second parte I wil declare that true religion is a most ex
• ellent and diuine thinge,The contents of the 2. part. not consisting only in conceite and • pinion of men, but flowing from the very fountaine of nature • t selfe; as being the end whereto aswel euery man, as also com
• onwealth is naturally ordayned; and that therefore not only al • articuler actions of men, but also al policy and reason of state, 〈◊〉 to be leueled, and squired by the rule thereof, and that no
• hing can be truly political or good for state which swarueth • rom true religion, and lastly I wil proue that only one (to wit • he Christian Catholike religion) is truly political, or fit for gouernment of states.

5. Of these two parts, I present vnto thee, good Reader,The principal intention of the author in this treatise. at • his tyme, only the first, and although my principal intention • herein, is no other, but to show the weaknes of humane policy, • nd the necessity of true religion for the perfection thereof, ne
• ertheles for the better satisfaction of such as by reason of the • ubiect which I handle, may perhaps expect some furder dis
• ourse concerning state, I haue determined to touch some poli
• ical matters now and then by the way, as occasion shalbe offred, & to lay doune in the end some general aduises & rules of policy, • ot for men already practised in affaires of state (of whome I • hal euer be glad to learne) but for such only, as are willing to • pply them selues thereto, and haue no experience thereof, whome I desire to set in the high waye, & direct course of a • ound and perfect policy grounded on Gods grace, and true piety, to the end they may proceede to theyr practise, with more • ight, lesse danger, and better successe to them selues and the • rinces whome they serue, and consequently to the publike
good, which depēdeth on nothing more, then on the wel handling, and good successe of matters of state.

Hovv far the author meaneth to touch religion in this treatise.6. And for asmuch, as one part of my subiect being Religion, and I by profession a Catholique Priest, it may perhaps be imagined that I wil touch some matters, which may be offensiue or vngratful to such as professe the religion now established in our cuntry; I think good to aduertise thee, good Reader, that my meaning is not in this first part to handle any matter of religion now in controuersy betwixt protestants & Catholiques, neither yet in the latter, any furder then the same shal be necessarily conioyned with matter of policy;Atheists ar cōmon enemies both to Catholikes & prot • stāts. Only I desire such protestants or puritanes as shal read this part, to hold me excused, if for the confusion of their common enemies, and ours (I meane Atheists, for such are the Politikes whom I especially impugne) I alleadge some times some examples of Gods extraordinary assistance geuen to his seruants miraculously by his Angels, Saints, or otherwaise,VVhy examples of miracles are alledged in this treatise. seeing there can not be a more euident argument for the proofe of Gods prouidence, then the same; And if any man doute whether such miracles haue bene, or maye be donne in these our daies, I wish them not only to consider those few examples of our time, which I haue had occasion to mention, but also to enforme them selues sufficiently of the many most notable miracles showed by almighty God the last yere, at the Image of the blessed virgin Mary neere to Sichem in Brabant, which are so fresh in memory, and so euident in the parties who receaued benefit therby, that they can not with any show of reason be denied.Many notable miracles donne this last yere in Brabant. But no maruel if such things are douted of by some which heare of them in these daies, seeing the stupendious miracles of our Sauiour him selfe, and of his Apostles & seruants in al ages, haue not bene beleeued of al those that saw them, but of those only whom it pleased God to illuminate with his grace.Plutark, in the life of Coriola
• us. And therfor I say with Plutarke, and Heraclitus two painim Philosophers, that the greatest parts of Gods woorkes are vnknowne to men for lack of beleefe.

The errour of polityks proceedeth partly of Atheisme.7. Moreouer, whereas the errour of politikes, as wel in matter of state, as in religion, proceedeth in greate part of meere Atheisme (in respect that they beleeue not that God hath care of man, or taketh account of his actions, or disposeth of kingdomes,
and states at his pleasure) I haue therfore determined early to proue the prouidence of God in the affaires of men, • d especially in the gouernment of state, and to answere parti
• larly the arguments of the politikes, or Atheists,
A foundation layd for the proof of Gods prouidence.
F. R. P. in his resolution.
Cicero de legib li. 1.

8. Whereupon it followeth necessarily,The general and vniforme consent of al natiōs cerning Gods prouidence deriued from nature. not only that there is God, but also that his prouidence disposeth, & gouerneth the • aires of men; For whence could this vniforme consent, and • inion of Gods prouidence, and his deity springe, and flow into • e minds of al people & nations, in al times, and ages, but from • ture it selfe, for Cicero as saith. Omni in re consentio omnium gentium 〈◊〉 naturae putanda est; The consent of al nations in any thing vvhatsoeuer, is be accounted the lavv of nature: Cic. Tuscul. quaest. li. 1. and therfore whatsoeuer is vniuer
• , and cōmon to al men, must needs be natural; and being natu
• it can not be vaine, for as Aristotle saith. Deus & natura nihil fa
• nt frustra. God and nature doe nothing in vaine: as for example,Aristot. de caelo li. 1. sum. 6. te • . 32. man naturally inclined to learne, and know truth, to loue, and de
• e good, to hate and eschew euil, which inclynations, and de
• es in man were vaine, if there were no truth to be knowne, thing good which might be loued and desired, or nothing • d which might be eschewed. And so in like sort, if there were 〈◊〉 God to worshipp and serue, nor any deuine prouidence in • ans affaires, the natural inclination of man to religion, that is say, to the worship and seruice of God were vaine, and conse
• ently erroneous in nature, which were absurd to say. And this so manifest that wheras Aristotle teacheth that some things areAristot To. pl • . li. 1. c. 9.
euident to reason,As euident to reason that God is to be honored, as to sense that snovv is vvhite. Arnob li. 7. contra Gentes. and some to sense, he putteth for example 〈◊〉 the first, that God and our parents are to be honored; Whereof fait • he, whosoeuer douteth hath no lesse neede of punishment the • he should haue neede of sense, if he denied snow to bee white To which purpose also Arnobius saith, that he which deniet • that God made and gouerneth the world, hath neither vnderstanding, nor yet sight, or common sense.

9. For who is so sensles that shal behould and dewly conside • the very workes of nature, their immensity, multitude, an • beauty, their admirable effectes, their wonderful order, thei • conexion, and subordination in the heauens, in the ayre, in th • elements,VVorks of nature prooue that there is a God and Creatour of al things. in the earth, and in al creatures, especially in ma • himselfe (in whome there appeare so many miracles of natur • such art in the composition, such wisdome in the disposition such conformity of one parte to an other, and such perfectio • in the whole that he is worthily called Microcosmus, a litle wordl • who (I say) considereth this, and can doubt that there was som • Creator and Author therof, of infinit power and wisdome; Fo • who is so simple, that seeing a goodly pallace, of so excellent an • rare workmanship, that it draweth the eyes of al men to behol • it, doth not presently acknowledg it to be the worke of som • notable Architect; for a notable effect can not be with out notable cause.

10. Furthermore (to omit many other considerations whe • of I wil speake otherwhere) if a man note and consider the wonderful wisdome that appeareth in the harmonious compositio • of contraryeties, or as I may tearme it in the dissonant conco • of contrary motions and qualities in Gods creatures; as the motions,Diuers considerations forcing man to acknovvledge a Creator of infinit vvisdome and povver. of the sunne, and the moone, and other plannets, not onl • different one from another but also contrary to the motion o • the highest spheere, and yet al of them caried with such a perpetual, equal, and constant course, that thereof redoundeth th • vsual and ordinary counterchange of night and day, of monethe and yeeres, of winter and sommer, and al other tymes and seasons, necessary for the production of the fruite of the earth, an • the conseruation of al liuing creatures. And againe if we add • thereto the contrary qualities of the foure elements, reduced t • a temperature in the constitution of al earthly thinges, wher •
vpon
depend the 4. contrary humours in the body of man, and other liuing creatures, and those humours tempered also with • ertaine equality wherein consisteth the health, life, and con
• uation of the said creatures; If a man (I say) wil consider this, can not imagine either that it was at first ordained, or els it 〈◊〉 continued by chance, seeing there appeareth therein such an • finit wisdome, that no reason, wit, or wisdome of man, can • fficiently comprehend it.

12. This is so euident in reason that by the consideration • ereof the heathen Philosophers attained to the knowledge
of a deity,Rom. 1. for as S. Paule saith. By those thinges that are visible in th • vvordle, they came to vnderstād that there vvas an inuisible God vvho mad • the same; Hovv the heathen philosophers attained to the knovvledge of a Deity. knowing right wel by the light of reason that nothing can be cause and author of it selfe, and noting such a subordination of inferiour causes to superiour, and such a connexion, and coherence of al thinges visible on earth and in the heauens, that they easely ascended, as it were, by degrees, from the lowest to the highest, and so to the contemplation of the Author and gouernour of al, whome they concluded to be eternal with out begining or end, of infinit wisdome, bounty, maiesty and power, incomprehensible and ineffable; And therfore Simonides the Poët being asked of Hieron the tiran • of Sicily what God was;Cicero de natu deorum. li. 1. demanded a daies respite to answere, & being then asked againe his opinion, craued two daies more and after againe a longer time, and in the end said; That the mo • he thought vpon him, the lesse he knevv vvhat he vvas. And no maruail • seing he is infinitly great without quantity, infinitly good without quality, he moueth al thinges and is not moued, he changeth al thinges, and is not changed, he is in euery place, and contained in no place, euery where present, euery where whole, in a • thinges, and yet included in nothing, with out al things and excluded from nothing, vnder al things, and oppressed by nothing, aboue al thinges, and yet not eleuated, or sustained by any thinge, but sustaineth, and mantayneth al thinges, finally b • ing the cause, begininge, and end of al thinges, or rather al i • al, yet he neither is, nor can be said to be any thinge of al.

Psal. 96. The incomprehensibility of the deuine nature.13. So that in respect of his incomprehensibility we may we say of him with the Psalmist. Nubes & caligo in circuitu eius. Cloude • and darknes doe inuirone him; and Posuit tenebras latibulum suum He hath hidden himselfe in darknes, and yet considering the euident and shyning light of his deytie, most manifest in al hi • workes,Psal. 18. whereof the Psalmist also saith: The heauens declareth glory of God, and the firmament shovveth forth the vvorkes of his hande •
we may wel say with S. Paule; Lucem inhabtat, he dwelleth i • light;1. Tim. 6. which light neuertheles he calleth, Inaccessibilem, inaccessible; for although there is nothing more manifest then the cle • sonne of his diuinity; yet so infinit is his nature & so incomprehensible is the light thereof,Arist. metaph. 2. text. 1. that Aristotle him selfe confesset •
that the vnderstanding of man can no more comprehend the • euine essence, and the proprieties thereof (though they are • ost manifest in nature) then the eye of the owle can behold • e light of the sunne.

14. For this cause,The deuine nature insinuated by the old philosophers, vvith dyuers attributs. Arist metaph. li 1. Idem. Metaph. li. 12. text. vltimo. not only our deuines but also the olde • hilosophers being not able to expresse his infinite and ineffable • ature by any proper name, doe insinuate the same by many • tributes; Aristotle calleth him the First cause, the first mouer, and the • st beginning, to whom he ascribeth the gouerment of the worlde, • hich he compareth to a family, gouerned by one maister, or • ord, and to an army conducted by one General, Mercurius Tris
• egistus tearmeth him vnderstanding, nature, necessity, the b • gininge • idst, and end of al thinges. Plato calleth him the father, gouernour, and,
Mercut. in Paemandro cap. 3. Plato. in Timaeo. Parmen Sophis. phaedro. & li. 6. de rep.
Platoes doctrine concerning God & his prouidēce in the gouernment of the vvorld.

• ng of the vvorld, beauty, and goodnes it selfe, By the participation • herof al thinges that are good and faire, haue their name and • ture, in so much that he teacheth expresly, that God is only 〈◊〉 be beloued for him selfe, and nothinge else in the world to be • eloued, but for him; and that his prouidence extendeth it selfe, • ot only to the gouernment of the world in general; but also to • uery thinge in particuler, which he laboreth to perswade by • iuers symilitudes, & examples. As of a good Phisitian that hath • re to cure al diseases, aswel litle as great; Of a father, or maister • f a family, who looketh carefully to al thinges that are therein; • f a good gouernour that hath an eye & regarde to euery thinge 〈◊〉 the Cittie: And lastly to a Captaine-General of an army, who as it were the life, and soule thereof, and conducteth and gui
• eth it, and euery parte of it by his directions.

15. To which purpose Cicero also testifieth that the whole • hooles, as wel of the Peripatetiks, as Academicks, did teach,Cicero Acad. quaest. li. 1. that
• od is the soule of the vvorld, and the perfect vvisdome and prudence vvhich • uerneth al thinges in heauen, & in terris ea que pertinent ad homines, Cicero de finib & nut deo. lib. 3. and • ose thinges in earth which belonge to men; And the same as
• cero also witnesseth was the doctrin of the Stoikes. The foolish opinion of Epicurus reiected by al other philosophers. Cicero. de natura deorum. li. 2 Al which • hilosophers, reiected, and derided the ridiculous opinion of
• picurus who framed to himselfe, a fantastical cōceit of a certaine
• lle God, who he said had a delicate and a transparent body, and • ued in such continual ease & repose, that he would not trouble • imselfe with the gouerment of the worlde. In fauor of which
opinion some haue obiected out of our holy Scriptures that ou • Lord God after the creation of al thinges. Gen. 2. An obiection out of the scriptures in fauour of the opinion of Epicurus. Aug. de. Gen. ad lit. li. 4. c 1 & in senten. Aug apud Prosperum. 277. The obiection ansvvered by S. Augustin. Requieuit septimo die a • vniuerso opere, quod patrarat; Rested the 7. day from al the work • that he had made; as though his rest shoulde consist in not medling with the administration of the world, and gouernment o • his creatures; To which obiection S. Augustine answereth thus Creatoris omnipotentia &c. The omnipotent and deuine vertue an • power of the Creator is the cause of the subsistence or beinge o • euery creature, which deuine vertue and powre if it should a • any time cease from the gouernment of those thinges that i • created, the very kind and nature of al thinges must needes perish and fal to nothing. And therefore whereas our Sauiour sait •
Pater meus vsque nunc operatur. My Father doth worke euen vntil thi • time;Ioan. 5. he signifieth the continuance of his worke in the administration and gouernment of his creatures. In which respect th • Scripture also saith of the diuine wisdome,Sap. 8. that pertingit à fine &c. It reacheth from end to end strongly, and disposeth al thinge • sweetly. And to the same purpose the Apostle said to the Athenians;
Acts. 17. Hovv the vvord requieuit septimo die in Genesis are to be vnderstood. In ipso viuimus &c VVe liue, vve are moued, and haue our begining and being in him; that is to say in almighty God. For if he should with draw his hand or operation from vs, wee could neither liu • nor moue, nor haue any being at al: and therfore it is to be vnderstood that God did so rest from al his workes the 7. day, that h • made no newe creatures; and not that he ceased to conserue an • gouerne those which he had made.

Cicero l. 3. de nat. Deo 4.16. Thus farre S. Augustine in answer of this cauil, whereto 〈◊〉 also adde that, as Cicero saith very wel; He vvhich confesseth there i • a God and yet denieth him the gouernment of the vvordle, and the comunication of his grace, and goodnes to his creatures, contradicteth himself • and destroieth diuinity; for that he denieth to almighty God that vvhic • is most proper to the deuine nature, and most excellent in it, yea and taxeth him most absurdly eyther with want of wisdome (if he say that God knoweth not how to prouide for his creatures) o • with want of bounty and goodnes, if he say that he knowet • how to doe it and yet wil not, or els with lack of power, if h • wold doe it and can not.The author of nature foūtaine of al goodnesse and vvisdome. For reason and philosophy teachet • that the author of nature, beinge the fountaine of al goodne • and wisdome, as I haue said, yea goodnes and wisdome it self •
• ust needes be of such infinite bounty that he wil not forsake • d neglect his owne creatures; and of such infinite wisdome • d power that he both knoweth how to prouide for them, • nd also is able to doe it; not with labour and toile, as Epicurus
• olishly imagined, but with al facility, by his only wil and • oord; conforme to that which the Psalmist saith of the creation • f al thinges: Ipse dixit & facta sunt, ipse mandauit & creata sunt; Psalm 148.
• e spake the vvord and al thinges vvere made, he commanded and they vvere • cuted; No maruel that God gouerneth and moueth al things by his only vvil seeing the soule doth the like in the body of man. Seneca de consolat. ad Heruan. ca. 8. Gen 1. &. 2. Psal. 8. And this the Stoicks did shew by a very euident and fa
• iliar example of the soule of man, which with the only wil • oueth and gouerneth the body and euery parte thereof as it • steth. And euen so (saie they) al thinges in the wordle are with facility made moued and changed by the wil and power of • od, whose deuine spirit (as Seneca saith) is equally dispersed • roughout al • he whole, per maxima & minima, as wel through • e least as through the greatest thinges.

17. And now to adde a word or two of Gods particular pro
• dence in mans affaires, can it be with any reason denyed, that • e hath a more special care of man, then of al other thinges in • rth, seeing he ordayned al earthly thinges for him, and him for • s owne seruice, creating him to his owne Image,The great care and loue of God tovvards man. and induing • m with a reasonable soule, capable of the knowledg of his • uine nature, to the end he might loue worship and serue him? • his not only our holy Scriptures, but also the most learned • ilosophers doe acknowledg, as Trismegistus, Plato, Aristotle, Trismegist. in Paemādro ad Ta •
trū. & ad Asclep. Plato in Timaeo & li. 4. de legib. & in Alcibiade Aristot. li. 10. Ethic. Iamblic. Porphirius. Plotinus, apud Marsil Fianum in Compendio in Timaeum. c 6. The consideratiō of religion and of the Church of Christ ministreth inuincible proofes of Gods prouidence. & al
• atonickes and Peripateticks who do constitute & place the end and • icity of man, in the knowledge and contemplation, loue and • orship of God, yea in a perfect coniunction, amytie, and vnity • ith him, as I wil proue at large in the second part of this Trea
• e, where I shal purposely speake of the dignity, fruit, and ne
• ssity of Catholike religion in commonwealth; the consideration • hereof wil afford most inuincible proofes of the infinit wis
• me, power, bounty, maiesty and prouidence of almighty • od, manifestly seene aswel in the perspicuous euidence, purity, • d excellency of the Christian Catholike faith, as also in the • mirable institution of the ecclesiastical monarchy, that is to say • e Church of Christ, and in the conseruation thereof so many • ndereth yeares togeather against the fury of al infernal and

terrestrial power, besides the manifest concurrence of a diuin • prouidence in the wonderful force of holy Sacraments in God • Church, and power of holy men both dead and liuing, and thei • stupendious, and miraculous workes.

18. Al which as they are necessarie for the perfection of commonwelth (as I wil make it euident) so doe they infallibly demonstrate the course of Gods prouidence therein, and therefore in both respects are to be handled by me amply in the secōd parte of this Treatise, and sometimes touched by occasion in this first part, wherein also the prouidence of God in the dispositio • of mens affaires,Hovv the prouidence of God in mens affaires shalbe proued in this treatise. shal be sufficiently proued, by the infirmity of man, and his natural seruitude and bondage to almighty God by the consideration of Gods miraculous operation in the ouerthrowe of mans policy and power: by the dependance of a • humaine designments or actions on the wil of God: by his disposition of States and kingdomes, by the punishment thereof fo • sinne. And lastly by the very arguments of Athiests themselues which shal not only be clearly confuted, but also proued to b • notable proofes of Gods prouidence.The Conclusion of the preface.

19. And because al these pointes shable sufficiently debate • and confirmed in the discourse followinge, I remitt thee (goo • Reader) thereto, and wil conclude this preface concerninge th • prouidence of God with S. Augustin; who explicateth notabl • this our Christian doctrine,Aug. solilo q. ca. 14. in these wordes; for asmuch (sait • he) as thou, o Lord, gouernest al thinges dwelling within the • and art alwaise present in euery place, and hast care of euer • thinge that thou hast made, thou art so attentiue to that whic • I doe, and dost keepe such watch ouer mee day and night, a • though thou hadest forgoten al other thinges in heauen & had care of nothinge but me;A notable saing of S. August. concerning the prouidence of God. for the immutable light of thy ligh • is neither the greater for seinge one only, nor the lesse for beholdinge diuers and innumerable thinges; For as thy sight do • comprehend perfectly al thinges togeather, so with the sam • perfection it comprehendeth euery thinge particularly, and co •
sidereth al thinges as wel as euery one, and euery one aswel as a • without diuision or diminution, or any change on thy part, & Thus saith S. Augustin of Gods particuler prouidence, whic • shal suffise concerning the same for this time.

20. Now then to come to the point which I determined • st to handle in this discourse, to wit, the insufficiency of al 〈◊〉 maine policy for the gouernment of state, two thinges are • st to be considered for the declaration thereof; The one is the • tural infirmity of man; And the other, the condition and state cōmonwelth; both which pointes I wil handle with as great • rspicuity as my determined breuity wil permit.

div.head: THE TABLE OF THE CHAPTERS SHEVVING THE CONTENTS of the first part of this Treatise.

list.item: AN epistle of the author to his sonne wherein he aduertiseth him what he wold wish him to obserue in this Treatise.

The preface wherin it is declared who are politiks, hovv they erre i • matter of Religion, and hovv they differ from other heretikes; Also wh • is the principal intention of the author in this Treatise; And finally som • grounds are laid for the proofe of Gods prouidence in humane affaires.

For the proofe of the imperfection, and insufficiency of al humane policy the natural imbecillity of man, and weaknes of his wit, with the caus • therof are declared; And by the way it is signified what danger, and d •
triment grovveth to man by selfe loue, and presumption of his ovvne wi • with an exhortation to humility. Cap. •

A further declaration of the infirmity of man, and the imbecillity of 〈◊〉 wit, and policy by the consideration of his natural bondage to almigh • God, and of his blindnes, and ignorance in his ovvne affaires, and cons •
quently of the necessity of Gods prouidence for his gouernment, & directio • as wel in publik as priuat matters. Cap. •

For the more ample proofe of the insufficiency of humane wit a • policy, diuers examples are alleaged of the errour of politiks, and world wise men in matters concerning them selues, and their states, by occasi • vvherof it is also debated how farre a man may trust a reconciled ene • and how true prudence, and Christian charity may concurre vvith distr • and suspicion. Cap. •

By occasion of the former examples it is debated whether the Emper •
Charles the 5. did prudently in passing through France vpon a sa • conduct, and of the danger he was in, and how he escaped; Also conc •
ning the errours of Henry the 3. King of France in the slaughter of 〈◊〉 Duke of Guise, and the Cardinal his brother. Cap. •

Of Errours committed by vvhole Senats, namely of Rome, and Veni •
vvith the conclusion of the premisses, and an admonition to politikes conc •
ning their folly and ingratitude towards almighty God. Cap. •

The vveakenes of al humane policy is proued by the nature of comm •
vvelth, that is to say by the natural mutability, and instability therof, •
emplified breefly in Empires, Kingdomes and other States. Cap. •

The imbecility of mans wit, and policy is furder proued by the imperfe
• on of al political science, with a consideration of the imbecility of law- • ker • , exemplified in Solons lawes, by occasion wherof a political que
• on is debated concerning sedition. Cap. 7.

The imbecility of law makers is also exemplified in certaine wicked, and
• surd lawes of Licurgus, Plato, and Aristotle, with certaine obserua
• ns no lesse pious then Political. Cap. 8.

The imperfection of humane lawes, is shewed by the defects incident to
• w; and first what law is, to what end it is ordained, and what it can • forme in commonwelth. Also an exact comparison of the law of the flesh • ugnant to commonwelth with political law, wherby it appeareth that • litical law can not suppresse the carnal law. Cap. 9.

An answere to an obiection made in fauour of political law, supposed be sufficient for the suppression of vice, if it take sufficient order for the • od instruction, & education of youth whereof the impossibility is shewed, • d in conclusion the necessity of the law of grace to supply the defecte of po
• ical law is inferred. Cap. 10.

The insufficiency of humane policy is furder proued by the vnce • tainty of
• e successe of mens wisest designments, and for the better explication therof is declared what are fate, fortune, and chance, and that according to the • nion of the best Philosophers fate doth not derogat from the freedome of • ans wil, and much lesse from the prouidence of God; and by the way some • athis said of Astrology, and force of the starres. Cap. 11.

A furder consideration of fate, and fortune, according to our Christian
• ith, and the doctrin of our holy Scriptures, and how almighty God woor
• th his wil in the affaires of men, by casual, and accidental meanes. Cap. 12.

Dyuers examples of sundry accidents, wherby the plots, and desygnments greate politikes haue bene dissipated, and ouerthrown; And concerning • ices that for a time haue bene proffitable, and in the end haue proued percious. Cap 13.

Of the force of suddaine chances, and vnexpected euents in the ouerthrow wel of mans power, as of his policy; And of the hazards, and doutful • ents of battailes, and other enterprises of warre, and that al the successe • erof dependeth vpon the prouidence of God, geuing victory sometimes by • ret concurrence with secondary causes, and sometimes by manifest, and • iraculous meanes. Cap. 14

For the furder proofe that the successe in vvarre depēdeth vpon Gods vvil,
• d prouidence, examples, are aleadged of miraculous victories in euery age •
since our Sauiours time, with the conclusion of this point concerning chances and vnexpected euents. Cap. 15.

The insufficiency of mans policy and povver, for the conseruation of commonvvelth is shevved by the consideration of Gods Iustice in the punishment, translation, and subuersion of states for sinne, vvhich point is handled in 7. chapters next ensevving; And first the Iustice of God in punishing the sinnes of men is proued by arguments drawn from nature it selfe. Cap. 16.

For the more euident proofe that God ouerthroweth states and kingdome for sinne, it is first proued that they depend on his prouidence; Also it i • signified for what causes God geueth the gouernment of kingdomes, or states to men; And finaly for what kind of sinnes, and in what cases he punisheth, or destroieth whole commonvvelths. Cap. 17.

Examples of the seuerity of Gods Iustice vpon kingdomes, and states f • sinne; And first of the subuersion of the most potent empire of the Chaldaeans, and of their admirable citty of Babilon, and for what sinnes the sam • was ouerthrovvn; And that the euents therof testified by proane authors ansvvered exactly to the prophesies in our holly Scriptures. Cap. 18

Of the destruction of Hierusalem, and of the greate calamityes of th •
Iewes euersince for their sinnes, and hovv the prophesies of Daniel and 〈◊〉 our Sauiour him selfe were fulfilled therin, wherby the prouidence and Iustice of God is euidently proued. Cap. 19
Other examples of Gods seuere iudgements vpon commonwelths for sinn • and particularly for negligence in the execution of Iustice vpon offender • and for the sinnes of the flesh. Cap. 20

That the three conquests of our cuntry by the Saxons, Danes, an •
Normans, proceeded of the sinnes either of the princes, or of the people or of both; and what their sinnes were which deserued so greate a p •
nishment; Also by the way it is discoursed, what greate mercy God sh •
vved tovvards the Britons, and English from time to time. Cap. 21

Of the conqu • st of the kingdome of Naples by Charles the 8. King o •
France, for the sinnes of the kings therof, vvith the conclusion inferrin • vpon the premisses, the prouidence, and iustice of God in the dispositio • of states, and the insufficiency of man for the gouernment therof vvithou • Gods assistance. Cap. 2 •

The imbecility of mans vvit is furder discouered by the ansvvere of certaine obiections of Atheists against the prouidence of God, and first som • vvhat is saide of the inscrutability of Gods Iudgements, and of mans ignorance in ordinary, and triuial things; And hovv that ignorance is the m ••
• er of Atheisme, Cap. 23.

The obiections of the Atheists are discussed, and ansvvered, vvherby it
• peareth that their arguments against Gods prouidence are notable and • dent proofes of the same; And first hovv it standeth vvith the prouidence, • stice, and mercy of almighty God to suffer so much sinne, euil, and mischeef the vvorld. Cap. 24.

Of the affliction of good men in this life, and that the same is a notable
• gument as vvel of Gods prouidence, bounty, and iustice, as of his loue them, vvith much comfortable doctrine for the afflicted seruants of • od. Cap. 25.

Of the great longanimity, & pacience of almighty God tovvards vvicked
• en, and of the causes of their prosperity, by occasion vvherof their pit
• ul, and miserable state is declared, vvith some good admonitions to • m. Cap. 26.

Of the variable, and vncertaine euents, that are common to good and
• il men in this life, as vvhy the good, and bad, do many times prosper, or 〈◊〉 afflicted alike; Also vvhy one man is some times punished for the faults an other, vvhy some are chastised in this life, and others not, and finally • hy almighty God doth manifest his Iudgements to man in some things, • d concealeth them from him in some other; And that in al this the proui
• nce of God clearely appeareth. Cap. 27.

It is inferred vpon the premisses that no sinful policy can be truly counted
• ise or political, and by occasion therof it is declared vvhence true vvisdome vvhat it is, and vvherein it consisteth; As also the difference betvvixt • isdome, prudence, and policy, and lastly the necessity of grace to the per
• tion of policy is signified; vvith a consideration of the dangers, and diffi
• ties incident to matter, of state. Cap. 28.

Certaine general rules or aduises no lesse pious then political, for the
• struction of such as desire to manage matters of state, and haue no ex
• rience therof, to the end they may deale therin with lesse danger, and dif
• ulty. Cap. 29.
Other general rules for a yong statist aduanced by his princes fauour to of his councel; as what he is to consider in him selfe, in his prince, and in • e matters that are to be consulted. Cap. 30.

VVhat a councellour ought to consider in his prince, as namely his consci
• ce, his commodity, and his reputation. Cap. 31.
VVhat a councellour is to consider in matters to be consulted. Cap. 32.

For the better, and more particuler instruction of yong statists concerning
matters to be consulted, a matter of state is debated, to wit what is to 〈◊〉 considered in a deliberation touching the maintenance of a ciuil warre, in forraine cuntry. Cap. 33

An other question is debated for the furder instruction of a yong statist to wit, whether a princes state can be assured by wicked policy, by the occasion wherof many principles of Macchiauel, and of the politikes his followers are examined, and confuted by reason of state, without the consideration of Gods Iustice. Cap. 34

The argument of the last chapter is prosecuted with the consideration o • Gods iustice in punishing wicked princes by the ministery of al his creatures Also some what is said of the enormity of murders, and Gods seuere punishment therof. Cap. 35

It is furder debated whether al sinful policy be against reason of state, by occasion wherof some things are obserued touching the course of Gods prouidence in the conseruation and dectruction of states and by the way som • what is said of sorcery, and how dangerous the practise therof is to princes And finally it is concluded, that al wicked policy is pernicious to state, an • that the wisdome of politikes, or Macchiauillians is neere folly. Cap. 36
