div.head: FOR THE PROOFE OF THE IMPERfection and insufficiencie of humaine policy; the natural infirmitie of man, and the imbecillitie of his vvit, vvith the causes ther • f are declared. And by the vvay it is signified, vvhat danger and detriment grovveth to man by selfe loue and presumption of his ovvne vvit, vvith an exhortation to humilitie. CHAP. I.
div.p:
WEE read in Plutarke that there were certaine sentences grauen vpon the gate of Apolloes temple at Delphos, whereof one, was,Plutarke: vpon this vvord. E •
grauen vpon the gate of Apolloes Temple. as it were, a salutation of the people to Apollo, containing a certaine profession of their faith, and beleefe of his Deitie; which the diuel who de
• uded them in that Oracle, ascribed to him selfe. An other was 〈◊〉 good lesson or aduise of Apollo to the people, in recompence • herof; The first was, this word Ei in greeke, which signifieth
• hou art, whereby the diuel who alwayes seeketh to be honored • s God, tooke vnto him selfe the proper and true title,The diuel affecteth the title proper to Diuinitie and attri
• ute of diuinitie, alluding to the name which God geueth to • im selfe in the Scripture, to wit, Ego sum qui sum, I am he which •• m. The other (to wit Apolloes lesson, Exod. 6.3. or aduise to man) was 〈◊〉
h • se-auton, know thy selfe: that is to say, know thy owne imbecillitie or weaknes.

2. Therfore to transferre this from the Gentils to vs Christi
• ns, and to apply it to my present purpose;The knovvledge of God, induceth mā to the knowledge of him selfe Arnob. lib 7. contra Gentes. I say that these two • ent • nces haue such rel • tion, and correspondence, the one to the other, that by vnderstanding the first, we may come to the consideration of the latter, and by the knowledge of the latter, we shal the better conceaue the first For as Arnobius noteth very wel if we know and consider that God only is, that is to • ay, that he only hath essence, and being, of him selfe, as being
the first and principal cause of al natural causes and effectes, t •• Author, Creator, Moouer, and Conseruator of al thinges, 〈◊〉 cannot, but consequently acknowledge that we haue no tr •• essence, nor being of our selues, and therby we come also to t •• knowledge of our owne fraylty, and infirmitie; which is the fo • said lesson that Apollo gaue vnto man, in saying gnoth • se-au • Know thy selfe. The knovvledge of our selues, induceth vs to the knovvledge of God. Againe this knowledge of our selues, inducet • and leadeth vs in some sort to the knowledge of God; for whe • we wel consider our owne imbecility, frailty, and mortality with the mutabilitie, and inconstancy of humaine thinge • we easily perceaue that we are not absolute or yet haue any tr •• being of our selues, but that we depend as al other thinges do • vpon some supernatur • l power, that is to say, vpon the common Father, Author, and Creator of nature and of al natur •• thinges: and so we come to vnderstand, not only that there is 〈◊〉 God,Plato in. Alcib. but also what is our duty, and obligation to him, in respe •• of our dependance vpon him. Therfore Plato teacheth tha • to the attaining of vertue and wisdome, two thinges are most r •
quisite in man, the first, to know God, and the second to kno • him selfe.

3. Now then; one of the greatest impediments that hinde • man from knowing either God or him selfe,Presumption a great impediment to man for the knovvledge of God, and of him selfe. is a vaine conceit • and presumption, that many men haue of their owne witt • and sufficiency, which draweth them into infinite errors, absu •
dities, and dangers, both of bodie and soule: for it ingendret • in them obstinacie, arrogancy, a spirit of contention, contradiction, and singularity, indignation and disdaine of other me • contempt of counsel, and of al help, humaine and diuine; an • not only error, but also heresie, infidelity, and atheisme. F •• those that presume ouermuch of their owne wittes, and me •
sure al thinges therby, doe commonly beleeue no more the • they know, and vnderstande: and therefore seeing them selu •• vnable to sound the depth of Gods iudgementes or to compr •
hend many misteries of our Christian & Catholique faith, with in the compasse of their capacitie, they fal many times into fla • heresie, or atheisme.

4. This disease of presumption (for so I may tearme it bein • a mortal sicknes of the soule) is much the more dangerous f ••
that it so affecteth,The presumption of a mans ovvne vvit most dangerous, and vvhy. or rather infecteth & blindeth the vnder
• tanding of man, that euerie one seeth it sooner then he that is •• cke therof, who cōmonly thinketh him selfe to be very sound • nd wel. For reason, which in the diseases of the bodie is able • o iudge thereof aright, being it selfe wel at ease, is in this case •• e parte it selfe that is diseased, being possessed with such a • hrensie that it perceaueth no more the lamentable case it is in, •• en doth a madde or frantike man see his owne madnes: in • hich respect it is in very manie incurable; for that they take • uch pleasure in their owne sickenes, that they wil admit no • ure, nor so much as anie counsel for their remedie.

5. And truely if we consider how general the infection ther
• f is amongst men, though not in al a like, and how few there • re that perceaue it in them selues; we shal see what cause we al • aue, (for I admonish my selfe herein as wel as others) to feare • east we haue some touch thereof, more or lesse. And to this • urpose, let euery man examine him selfe, how often in his life, • e hath held & stifly defended some false conceite and opinion • f his owne, how apt he is stil to doe the like;Hovv generally the infection of presumption raigneth. how wel he li
• eth his owne doinges; how loath he is to confesse an error, or • o seeme to be ignorant, or yeld to an other man: let euery one (I say) consider this wel, and he shal see what cause he hath to • uspect some spice of this phrensie in him selfe, which wise men ought the rather to eschew, and abhorre, for that it is the pro
• er disease of fooles; for as our English prouerbe saith, None so • old as blind Bayard, nor any man more confident of his owne witt, and knowledge, then he that hath least, or none at al.

6. Wheras on the other side, the wiser a man is, the better • e seeth and considereth, as wel the general imbecillitie, and weaknes of man, as his owne particuler defectes, from the which no man in this life can be free;No man vvithout some defect. and weighing wel how • itle al that he knoweth is in respect of that which he knoweth not, and how vncertaine al humaine knowledge is, & how subiect to error, he acknowledgeth his owne frailtie, & ignorance, Non alta sapiens (as the Apostle saith) sed humilibus consentiens,
Rom. 12. not conceauing highly of him selfe (nor medling with matters aboue his reach) but limiting his conceites in al humilitie within the compasse of his capacitie, which is a necessarie & essential
point of true wisdome,The cause of mās natural infirmitie, and the vveaknes of his vvit. as I wil declare more at large hereafte • But to th'end that the natural infirmitie of man, and his ignorance may the better appeare, the cause therof is first to be co •
sidered, for so we shal the better vnderstand the effect.

7. Therfore although man at his first creation, had al th • powers of his soule vigorous, & perfect in their nature, promp • and readie to the execution of their functions,Original Iustice lost by the fal of Adam. as his reaso • and vnderstanding cleare, his wil and affection ordinate, an • inclyned to good, and his sensual powers so bridled by origina • iustice, that they yealded due obedience to reason: Yet whe • original iustice was lost by the fal of our first father Adam, an • the light of Gods grace extinguished, not only reason was muc • weakned, and the wil disordered, but also the sensual powe • so corrupted,S. Tho. 1. 2. q. 85. art. 3. or rather infected, that they haue euer since runn • head-long to their obiects with such violence, that they commonly draw the wil after them: whereof diuers reasons may b • giuen, but one or two shal suffice, to wit, that althou • h the wi •• be so placed betwixt reason and sense, that it may inclyne it self • to either, yet it contracteth a kind of frendshippe, and amiti • with sensuality, a long time before it be acquainted with reaso • (as we see by experience in children, who are some yeares ledd • by sense, before they come to the vse of reason) wherupon i • followeth,The vvil often ouercome by sensuality. that the wil hauing alreadie found the passion of sensualitie, stronge, familiar, and pleasant, and after feeling the fir •• motions of reason, weake, vnwonted, and disgustful, doth presently giue it selfe so fully ouer to the pleasures of the sense • that it hardly recouereth it selfe euer after; especially seeing w • can neuer come to the future good that reason promiseth vs, b •• by the conquest of concupiscence, and sensualitie, the whic • geuing vs present paiment of an apparant good (to wit pleasur • and delectation) entangleth & bewitcheth vs in such sort tha • we are cōtent to rest, & repose therin; yea & to yeald our selu •• prisoners to pleasure, and to desist from the pursuite of the future good, and true felicitie that reason promiseth vs.

Homer. Hes • od. Ouid.8. This the Poets represented in the companions of Vlisse •
who returning with him towardes Ithaca, where they were t • receaue the reward of their labours, were so bewitched by th • way with the pleasant, and delectable cuppes of Cyrces, that the •
would passe no further, but remained with her,Vlisses companions transformed into beasts by Cyrces. and were trans
•• rmed into beastes: as in truth al those may be said to be, that •• nding to the true felicitie which nature hath proposed to man • e so drunken by the way with the delight, and pleasures of •• e world and the flesh, that they giue them selues ouer therto, •• d bec • mme, Sicut equus & mulus quibus non est intellectus.
Psal. 31. Like a • se, or a mule that hath no vnderstandinge.

9. Wel then, the wil of man being thus peruerted, what mar
•• ile is it,VVhen mans vvil is peruerted by sensuality his vnderstanding is easily ledde in to error. if reason and vnderstandinge be so corrupted therby •• at it be drawne to error; for we see, that as men are affected, 〈◊〉 commonly they vnderstand and iudge: in which respect loue called blind, for that it obscureth and blindeth the vnderstan
•• ng of man in such sorte, that it can not descerne the truth.
• fficile est (saith the latin prouerbe) amare & sapere It is hard to •• ue, and to be wise. For where affection beareth swaie, reason is •• rced to obey, and therfore no man is thought to be a compe
•• nt and fit iudge in his owne cause,Arist lib. 6. Et • cap. 4. nor yet in the cause of those • home he dearely loueth. And for the same reason Aristotle af
•• rmeth: that intemperance corrupteth the iudgment of man, • ecause the wil being seduced and the affection drawne therby,Intemperance, corrupteth mans iudgement.
•• e light of reason and vnderstanding is so obscured & darkned • y passion, that it can not discerne good from euil. And the same 〈◊〉 also signified in the booke of wisdome, where the Holy Ghost • eclaring the cause why a good man is some tymes taken sud
• ainly out of this life, saith, Raptus est, ne malitia mutares intellectis.
Sap. 4.
• e was taken suddainly away, least malice or inordinate affection, should • ange, or corrupt his vnderstanding. Therfore although reason since • e fal of our first father,VVhat dominion reason hath ouer the sensual povvers. doth stil retaine so much dominion • uer the sensual powers, that it may subdue them with the assi
•• ance of the wil, rectified and guided by grace; yet when the wil 〈◊〉 peruerted, reason either is wholy seduced and deceaued ther
• y, or at least remaineth so weake, and powerles, that it looseth • he commaund and dominion which it ought to haue, and ther
• ore the Poët saith; Video meliora probóque, deteriora sequor. Ouid. Metam. lib. 7. in prine. I see and • pproue that which is best, but I followe the worst.

10. Hereto I may adde also an other reason of the error in mans vnderstanding, to wit, the difficultie of the obiect therof, for that truth, (which is the obiect of the vnderstanding) is not
only inuolued,The difficulty of the obiect of mans vnderstanding. and wrapped like the kernel of the nutte, in 〈◊〉 many shells & rindes of abstruse doubtes, and difficulties, th • many times it is hardly found, but also it is so incountred wi •• falshood and error, disguised with the shew & apparance 〈◊〉 veritie, that the best wittes are often deceaued there with; a •• therefore no maruaile if the wisest men of the world doe ma •• times goe astray, stumble, & fal into the obscuritie of the manifold, and intricate doubtes, questions, controuersies, perplexities, & vncertaine euentes that daily occurre in humaine affaires.

The opinion of man • principal philosophe s cōcerning the imbecility of mans vvit. Cicero. A cad: quest: li. • . & 2. 11. This the wisest Philosophers did so wel consider, that man • of them affirmed; that nothing in this world can certainly b • knowne and vnderstood, by reason of the error in mans sense • imbecil • tie of their wites, breuitie of their liues, and the obsc •
ritie of truth; of which opinion were, Socrates, Plato, Democrit •• Anaxagoras, Empedocle, and al the new Academicks; in so muc • that Socrates was iudged by the Oracle, to be the wisest man the • liuing, because he was wont to say, Hoc solum scio, quod nihil s •• I know only this, that I know nothing; whereto Archesilaus adde • that not so much as that could be knowne, which Socrates sai • he knewe, to wit; that he knewe nothing. And although the ••
Philosophers, may seeme to haue exceeded in exaggerating the ignorance of man (therby to represse, & correct, as it may b • thought, the presumption that many men had of their ow • knowledge, and wisdome) yet they sufficiently signified therb • their conceit of the weakenes of mans iudgement, and imbecilitie of his wit.

12. Therefore to reduce the extremities of opinions in thi • matter to a meane,The vvisest man doth often erre vvithout the help of Gods grace. I neither wholy euacuate and annihilate ma • knowledge and prouidence, as they seemed to doe, neither ye • with others extend, and enable it further then may be iustl • granted to mans imbecilitie. For as I confesse that man (thoug • corrupt of nature, and weake in wit and iudgment) may neuertheles, with the ordinarie concurrance, and assistance, that Go • geueth to his creatures, know, foresee, & determine man • thinges notably, both for his priuate, and publike good; so I also affirme, that except he haue some supernatural light of God • grace to illuminate his vnderstanding, and to rectifie, and guid •
his wil, the wisest man shal many times absurdly erre: and that •• erfore it is conuenient, for euery man, how wise soeuer he • old him selfe to be, to acknowledge the same in al humilitie to •• mighty God, and to craue true wisdome of him,An exhortation to humility as his special •• ft, following the example of the wise man, in the booke of • isdome which treating of the excellency of true wisdome, and • cknowledging it to be the special gift of almighty God, craued 〈◊〉 at his handes, and withal signified notably, the weaknes of • ans wit and iudgment, with the reason thereof, in these wor
• es; Da mihi domine &c:
Sap. 9. Giue me o Lord (saith he) that wisdome which as
•• steth thy seate and cast me not of from the number of thy seruantes, for that 〈◊〉 am thy bondslaue, and the sonne of thy bondwoman, a weake man and of • orte l fe, vnable to vnderstand aright vvhat is iustice and lavve, The imbecillity of vvit ac • novvledged by Salomon. and who
•• euer is the most perfect and excellent amongst the sonnes of men, he is to be •• counted as no bodie, if thy vvisdome doe not assist him; for the cogitations • f mortal men are doubtful and feareful, and al our prouidence is vncertaine, 〈◊〉 reason that the corruptible bodie doth aggrauate the soule, and this earthly • abitation doth depresse the vnderstanding.

13. This, and much more to this purpose saith the wise man • r rather the Holy Ghost by him,True vvisdom the particular gift of almighty God. teaching that true wisdome is • he particular gift of almighty God, and that without the light • f his grace, mans iudgment, and vnderstanding is obscure, his • onceits, and designements ful of doubt and feare, his proui
• ence, and foresight vncertaine, and therefore Salomon wisely • duiseth. Ne innitaris prudentiae tuae &c. Rely not vpon thy ovvne vvis
• ome, but in al the course of thy life thinke vpon God,
Prouerb. 3. and he shal direct thy •• epps. And to the same purpose Ecclesiasticus saith, Ne te extollas &c: • oe not extolle thy selfe in thy ovvne conceite like a bul,
Ecclesi. 6. lest perhaps thy force • nd pride be beaten dovvne by folly, that is to say, lest for punishment of thy pride, God giue thee ouer to thy selfe, that thou maist fal by • hy owne folly. S Paul also exhorteth the Romaines, and in them • l other Christians, Non plus sapere quam opertet sapere,
Rom. 12. sed sapere ad •• brietatem. Not to be vviser then a man ought to be, but to be soberly or modestly vvise that is to say; that a man goe not aboue his reach, not (as I may tearm it) out of the sphere of mans infirmitie,Arist. lib. 1. & 3. de anima. nor attribute to him selfe greater perfection of nature then he hath, considering that though almighty God hath placed him in the highest degree of al those creatures that haue sense; yet he hath
giuen him the lowest ranke of those that haue vnderstand ••• hauing subordinated him to Angels,Angels may •• re in the iudgement of future things depēding on the vvil of God or of man. of whome those of 〈◊〉 most inferior and lowest order, haue an vnderstanding far m • cleare, and excellent then he; and yet so neuerthelesse th •• their knowledge is also limited. For if we consider them in th ••• owne nature, without the supernatural helpe of God, they 〈◊〉 erre, and be deceaued; as in the iudgement of things to co • that depend not vpon natural causes, but only vpon the wil 〈◊〉 God, or yet vpon the free wil of men.

14. Hereof the Phil • sophers were not ignorant, & th ••
fore Porphyrius the Platonick, seeking to giue some probable re •
son,Porphyr apud Io Picum Mirandul. cont. Astrologos. why the sp • rits that gouerned the Oracles, lyed many time saith; that
• hen they iudged of thinges to come by the starres, they mig •• be deceaued. And yet in the opinion as wel of Philosophers, as D •
uines, Angels haue a most exact, and certaine knowledge of natural causes,Angels haue a perfect and exact • novvledge of al natural causes. & of the effects therof, hauing naturally in the • selues the formes, or representations of al natural things, whi •• therfore they behold and see with al euidency, and perspicuit •• whereas man doth vnderstand nothing but by discourse, or b • meanes of phantasie, & sense, both which are greatly subiect 〈◊〉 error, in respect that they depend vpon an organ so corruptib •• as mans body is, which many tymes being il disposed, wholy oppresseth the vnderstanding,Plutar: in vita Catonis. (as we see in fooles and mad me • and doth obscure it more or lesse in al men. In which respec •
Nearchus the Pithagorian (as Plutark affirmed) was wont to cal th • body of man,Plato in Phaedon. pestem animae, the plague of the soule. And Socrates, Pla ••
and al their followers held most constantly, that the more th • soule is abstract from the senses, the more clearly it vnderstandeth; and that because in th • s life it can neuer be wholy separat • from the same, therfore it can neuer in this life attaine to perfec • knowledge & true felicitie.

Man ordayned to • upply the roome of Angells. Mat. 12. 15. This was their opinion, and being wel vnderstood, it i • not dissonāt from our Christian doctrin, which is, that althoug • man is ordayned to supply • he roome, and place of the Angell that fel, and therfore is made capable of their perfection, 〈◊〉 meane as wel of their knowledge as beatitude (in which respec • our Sauiour saith of soules glorified, sunt sicut Angeli, they are 〈◊〉 vnto Angells) yet he can not attaine vnto it in this life, which 〈◊〉
but as the way wherein he is disposed, led, and guided thereto • y the light of Gods grace; which disposition is to be perfected, • nd consummated by the light of glorie in the next life. Wher
• ore the Apostle saith, Ex parte cognoscimus, &c:Mans knovvledge most vnperfect in this life. we knowe in this •• fe, but only in parte, or vnperfectly, but when that vvhich is perfect shal •• me, (that is to say when we shal attaine to the vision of God, • nd perfect beatitude) then that vvhich is vnperfect shalbe euacuated; 1. Cor: 13. When I was a child, I spoke like a childe, I thought like a childe, I vnder
•• oode like a childe, But when I became a man I layed away al childishnes.
• hus saith the Apostle, signifying that as the vnderstanding and • nowledge of an infant, is most vnperfect, in respect of the • nowledge and iudgement of a man;Mans knovvledge to be perfited in the ne •• lyfe by the vision of God Ibid. Psal. 35. Aug: lib: de ciuitat: dei ca. 29. so is al the knowledge we • aue in this life most weake and vnperfect, in respect of that • hich we shal haue in the next, quando videbimus facie ad faciem, • hen we shal see God face, to face, & in lumine eius videbimus lumen, & 〈◊〉 his light shal see light. For as S. Augustin saieth of Angells, we •• al see al creatures more truly, and clearly in the wisdome of • od, then in them selues, by reason that we shal see them in •• eir cause, and in the very arte whereby they were made.

16. This I haue said to shew that he which attributeth to • im selfe, any perfection of knowledge or vnderstanding in • is life, exceedeth the limittes of mans nature, and taketh vpon him the knowledge of Angells, or of a soule gloryfied, whereto it is no more possible for any man in this life to arriue by any natural meanes, then for a beast or an vnreasonable creature, to attaine to the knowledge & vnderstanding of a man: which I wil yet make more euident in the next chapter.

div.head: A FVRTHER DECLARATION OF THE INfirmity of man, and his imbecillity of wit, with a considerati •• of his natural bondage to Almighty God, and of his blindn •• and ignorance in his ovvne affaires; And consequently of t •• necessity of Gods prouidence, for his gouernment and directio • as vvel in publike, as priuatte matters. CHAP. 2.
div.p:
AS selfe loue and presumption of a mans ow • witte are very discomendable in al such as a • infected therwith; so are they most hateful a •• hurtful in those,The dammage that ensueth of self-loue and presumption. that hauing good natural ••
lentes, and giftes of body and minde, doe with flowe in wealth, dignity, and authoritie, who vaine conceit of their owne sufficiency being seconded wi •• the pride of their prosperity, and confidence of their powe • makes them many tymes so insolent, that the wise man sait • of such kind of men: It is better to meete a raging Beare, that hath 〈◊〉 her whelpes,
Prouerb. 17. then a foole that is confident in his folly. For such co •
monly contemne both God and man, and runne such an vnbridled and exorbitant course, that they ouerthrowe, not only the • selues, but also al such as depend vpon them.

2. Therfore for as much as the sayinge of the royal prophet Dauid is truely verified in such men, to wit, homo cum in h •
nore esset,
Psal: 48. &c: man when he was in honor did not vnderstand, and th ••
fore was compared to brute beastes, and made like vnto them; I wish 〈◊〉 might happe vnto such men as we reade in the fable,A fable of a mule moralized in mans presumption. Plutarke in Conui • io Sapient. it chance once to a Mule in Lidia, which beholding in the water his ow • shape, & seeing his longe legges, his tall stature, his feiture ( 〈◊〉 it seemed to him) very faire and comely, his braue pack-saddl • adorned with plumes of feathers, bells, and other furniture, w • so transported with suddaine delight and ioy, that first he bega • to braye then to leape and kick, and after to runne: but as 〈◊〉 was in the midst of his carriere, he chanced to remember th •• his father was an Asse, that his longe legges and tall stature, w ••
giuen him to make him the more able to labour and toyle, and •• at his braue furniture, was but a saddle to carry a packe, and •• nally that he was borne, and ordeined to serue, and to beare • ot only burdens, but also stripes, if he did not his duty: which • hen he remembred, he was so confounded, that he suddainlie • aid his course, and retourned quietly to his accustomed labour • nd occupation. The like I say, I wish might happe to such as • dmiringe ouermuch their owne good partes, and the giftes • herewih God hath blessed them, are puft vp with such pride, •• at forgettting wholy both God & them selues, they run head
•• ng to their owne ruine and perdition. And therfore to re
• oke such men from their dangerous course, to walke the se
• ure way and trodden path, which nature hath laid open to • ad them to true honor and felicity, I wish that they would re
• ember, and consider certaine things figured, and represented, 〈◊〉 the fable of the Mule.

3. The first is, the state and condition of Man, Iob. 17. as that rottenes • nd filth (as Iob saith) vvas his father, that vvormes are his brethren, •• d sisters; that he is dust; and shal retourne to dust; being replenished • vith miseries, he florisheth and fadeth againe vvithin a vvhile like a • ovver, and vanisheth avvay like a shaddovve, and neuer remaineth in •• e state; such being the instabillitie of mans nature,The instability of mans nature. that the • ore we fix our cogitation theron, to find out some stay, and •• ue being therin; the lesse we find it, euen as, the more a man ••• resseth or wringeth water in his hand, the lesse he holdeth.Plutark vpon the vvord Ei.
〈◊〉 which respect Heraclitus was wont to say, that as a man can • ot enter twise into one and the selfe same running water or •• uer, by reason that it fleeteth, and passeth away continually; 〈◊〉 we cannot possibly find the substance and nature of man, wise in one state. For as time which measureth it, so changeth •• il, that one instant succeedeth and destroyeth an other, one • inute an other, one hower an other, one day an other, and • he like in weekes, monthes, and yeares: so also mans substance • nd life, which is measured, & wasted by time,Mans nature changeth euery minute of an hovver. Senec. ep. 24. suffereth change • nd mutation euery yeare, euery month, euery weeke, euery • ay, euery hower, euery minute, euery instant, vntil it be cleane • onsumed, in so much that our life (as Seneca saith) is but a conti
• ual death: for we are dailie and howerly dyinge, seing some
parte of our life is cut of euery day, and euery hower; not onl • in our old age, and decaying yeares, but also in the very flow • of our youth. For though then we growe and increase in ••
ture and strength, yet our life stil decayeth and decreaseth, sei •• we haue euery day so much lesse to liue. And as the voiding 〈◊〉 emptying of an hower glasse that is continually runinge, do •• not consist only in the falling of the last graine of sand,Seneca Ibid. but 〈◊〉 the whole defluction thereof from the very beginninge: so o • death, saith Seneca, doth not consist only in the last hower 〈◊〉 our life,Man alvvayes dying. when we cease to be, but in the wasting and consumi •• course thereof from our first natiuity: so that our last gaspe 〈◊〉 not so properly our death, as the end and cōsummation thereo • For although thereby we arriue to the periode of death, yet w • were goinge towardes it longe before.

Aug: de verb: Dom. Ser. 1.4. In this respect. S. Augustin saith very wel, that we shou •• haue lesse cause to feare, if we were made of glasse. For w ••
(saith he) is more fraile and brickle then glasse; and yet vve see it is ke •• and may continue whole ages. And although it be subiect to breaking 〈◊〉 accidents, yet there is no feare that it may perish, neither by old age or sic •
nes: S. Augustines discourse of the frailty and misery of Man. wheras we feare not only innumerable chaunces, which bringe 〈◊〉 to his end, and neuer ceasse to threaten his ruyn, but also the iniury of ty • which wasteth vs continually, so that we may auoid perhaps a blowe or fal, or such other mishaps, but vve can neuer auoid our end; vve may s ••• and eschewe, those perills which are external, but internal which da •• growe vvithin vs, vve cannot eschevve. Thus saith this graue, an • learned Father; which how true it is, daily experience doth d •
monstrate vnto vs, so that we may truely say with the Psalmi ••

23. Therfore to omit infinite other testimonies of Philosophers which might be alleaged, I conclude this point with t •• famous Seneca, who to confute the Athiestes of his time, and 〈◊〉 shewe withal their ingratitude towardes almighty God the •• Creator and Conseruator, rehearseth many benefites that ma • hath receaued of God, aswel generally in the heauens, as als • particulerly euery one in his owne person, and then addeth the •• wordes. Seing thou doest greatly esteeme (saith he) the •• gifts, why art thou so vngrateful, not to acknowledge th •• selfe a debtor to him that bestowed them vpon thee? When 〈◊〉 hast thou the very breath that thou drawest? Whence th • light, wherby thou disposest of thy actions? whence the •• blood wherin thy vital heat, and spirits are conserued? When •• those exquisite sauors, meats, and sauses, so aboundant th •• they euen tyre, and cloy thy appetite? Whence these prou •
cations of languishing pleasures? Finally, whence hast tho • this very ease, rest, and repose wherein thou wallowest an • wasts thy selfe? If thou be grateful, wilt thou not say, with th • poët:Verg. •• log 1. Deus nobis haec otia fecit, namque erit ille mihi semper Deus; th •• is to say, God gaue me the same, and he shal be my God for eue • And a little after he addeth. But if thou say, that not God, b • nature hath giuen thee al this, dost thou not vnderstand, th •• thou dost but change the name of God, and cal him nature, 〈◊〉
whom thou mayst apply what name soeuer expresseth any hea
• enly force, or effect, for so many may his names be, as he gi
• eth gifts. Ergo nihil agis, ingratissime mortalium. Therfore, Ibid. c. 7. & 8. The ingratitude of Atheists taxed by Seneca. o thou • ost vngrateful of al mortal creatures, thou dost but tryfle • hen thou sayest that thou art a debtor to nature, and not to • od: for God is neither without nature, nor nature without • od, but both is one, as if thou shouldst haue receaued a benefit • f Lucius Annaeus Seneca, and wouldst say, that thou art not a • etter to Seneca: but to Anneus, or to Lucius. Dost thou not see •• at thou chāgest not thy creditor, but his name? Euen so; what
•• euer thou callest God, be it nature, fate, or fortune, al are but •• uers names of one God, according to the diuers vse and exer
•• se of his power. Thus far Seneca; reprouing notably the ingra
•• tude of Atheists, as Cicero also doth, saying. Cicero. de legib li. 2. He that is vngratful to God deserueth not the name of a man. Horat. li. 2. ode 13. The second reason of mans insufficiency to prouide for him selfe, to vvit, because he knovveth not vvhat is conuenient for him selfe. Eccles. 7. Hierom in. li. Habac. ca. 1. A sound aduise of plato concerning vvhat man should craue of God. Ibid. Plato in Alcibiade 2. Hier. in ep. ad. Ephes. li. 2. ca. 4.
That he deserueth not the •• me of a man who inioying those things which the earth produceth for his • e, is not thankful to God for the same. Thus much for the dependan
• e of man vpon the wil and prouidence of God for his conserua
•• on, which is one of the two reasons that I intended to yeeld, • hy Gods help and direction is absolutly necessary for man.

24. The other reason is, because mans wit is so weake and • ind, that he knoweth not what is good and couenient for •• m selfe, and much lesse for others, where vpon the Poet saith?
• uod quisque vitet, nusquam homini satis cautum est in horas; that is to • y: No man is so wyse, and wary that he knoweth at al tymes what to •• oyde. And the booke of Ecclesiastes saith to the same purpose.
• uid necesse est? &c. VVhat needeth a man desire or seeke thinges aboue him ••• fe, seing he knoweth not so much, as what is necessary and conuenient •• r him selfe and in the dayes of his peregrination?

25. Therfore S. Hierom compareth almighty God, to a wise • hisition, who giueth not to his patient hurtful thinges, though •• e desire them neuer so instātly. And likneth man to a sick man, • ho many tymes desireth that which would be his death if it • ere granted him. In which case, Mercy (saith he) were cruelty: • uia voluntas tua contra te petit. Because thy owne wil desiers against • ee. Wherefore Plato giueth sound aduise neuer to craue of al
• ighty God absolutly any thing that partaineth to our temporal • ate, but with condition, to wit, if it be conuenient for vs: • r that as S. Hierome also saith in an other place; Id quod, oportes
orare nescimus, & saepè contra nos petimus, estimantes esse pro nobis! 〈◊〉 know not what it is conuenient to pray for, and many tymes we 〈◊〉 those thinges that are against vs, thinking that they be good for vs. A • the Apostle him self saith also to the same purpose. Roman. 8. Spirit ••
•
uat. &c. The spirit of God doth help our infirmity, for wee know not 〈◊〉 nor what wee should pray.

26. This is manifest by the vaine and foolish desiers of 〈◊〉 yea of the wisest, that wish and earnestly desier some tymes 〈◊〉 thinges as are most pernitious for them; In so much, that it 〈◊〉 wel be said vnto them, as our Sauiour said to his two Apos ••• who desired to sit the one on his right hand, and the other 〈◊〉 his left: Matt. 20. Nescitis quid petatis: You know not what you may 〈◊〉 wherefore Plato comendeth a certaine poet called Ion,
〈◊〉 when he heard his freends other whiles craue of God 〈◊〉 thinges as were not conuenient,A vvise prayer of a Pagan Poet. was wont to pray thus. O Iup • giue vs good thinges, wherther we aske them or no, but those thinges 〈◊〉 are euil giue vs not, Plat. in Alcib. 2. though we craue them neuer so much? And th • foolish desiers of men the Poetes signified by the fable of Pha •••
who hauing by his importunity,Ouid. metam: li. 1. & 2. obtained of his father Pha •••
the guiding of his chariot, burnt both the world and him sel •• And Cicero also signifieth the same by an other fable of Thaes ••
who craued of Neptune three wishes whereof one was the ••
struction of his owne sonne Hippolitus, Cicero. offic. lib. 3 which being obtain •• he remained al his life after most sorrowful and inconsolable.

The conclusion of this chapter inferring the necessity of Gods prouidence for mans conseruat • on.27. Seing then man is so weake of power and wit, that 〈◊〉 him selfe, he neither can sufficiently prouide for him selfe, 〈◊〉 ther yet knoweth what is conuenient for his owne estate, it f ••
loweth necessarily, that the prouidence of God his Lord 〈◊〉 Creator is most needful for his conseruation and directio • throughout the whole course of his life; nor only in his priua •• and particuler affayres, but much more in publike matters, p ••
taining to the gouernment of the commonwelth: for the be •• prooffe whereof, and of the insufficiency of al humaine wit 〈◊〉 policie, I wil laye downe some examples of the errors of so •• famous Politickes, who by their owne imprudence haue eith •• ouerthrowne, or else greatly indangered, them selues and the •• estates.

div.head: • OR THE MORE AMPLE PROOFE OF THE insufficiency of humane vvit and policy, diuers examples are alleaged of the errors of Politikes, and vvorldly vvise men. By occasion vvhereof it is also debated, hovv farre a man may trust a reconciled enemy, and hovv true prudence & Christian charity, may concure vvith distrust and suspition. CHAP. 3.
div.p:
LEWIS the eleuenth King of France, one of the most politicke Princes that France euer had,Philip de Comines de reb. gest. Lodouici. 11. in. cap. 33.
• eing at warrs with his owne brother Char • es duke of Normandy: Francis duke of Britany: and Charles duke of Burgundy, and desiring greatly to seperate the last from the other two, to the end • e might the better be reuenged on them, solicited him by his • mbassadors to come to conference with him, which the Duke
•• alded vnto, so that the meeting might be in a towne of his • wne in the frontiers of Flanders and France, Levvis the 11. of France ouertaken in his ovvne policy. for his better secu
•• ty: where with the King was wel contented. The meeting •• erfore being appo • nted at Peronne (whither the Duke was come • ith his army) and safe conduit sent to the king by a letter of •• e dukes owne hand, the king went thet • er without any for
• es or guard, to shew the confidence he had in the Duke, to the • nd to oblige him the more, and to gayne his good wil. But the
• uke seing now his enemy in his power, and vnderstanding at • he same time, that Liege was reuolted from him by the solicita
•• on of certaine Embassadors of the king, tooke him prisoner, • nd would not release him vntil he had recouered the towne of
•• ege, whither he forced him to accompany him with no smal • anger of his person And in the end hauing made him graunt to • ome hard conditions in fauor of his confederates (against • home the king had especially plotted that conference and • reaty) he released him.

2. Now then who seeth not in this example,The manifest error of King Levvis. how grosly • his great Politike erred in two things, wherein it might be presumed
that a man of any experience could not haue bene 〈◊〉 ceaued. The one, that hauing employed certaine agents or ••
bassadors, to stirre vp the towne of Liege against the Duke,
〈◊〉 did not countermaund it, when he resolued to put him selfe in 〈◊〉 his handes; for who could be so simple, as not to consider t ••• if the practise should take effect (as it did) whiles he should 〈◊〉 in his power, not only the peace and amity which he desired 〈◊〉 make, would be hindered therby, but also his person enda •
gered? For that the Duke should haue iust cause to detaine hi • at least vntil he had done him reparation of the wrong.

3. The other error was, that he would vpon any security 〈◊〉 safe conduit, put him selfe to the curtesy & mercie of his enem • without an vrgent, and ineuitable necessity; knowing how lit ••• assurance is many times in wordes or oathes, when present co •
modity either priuate or publike, is offered by the breach ther • Besides that, his owne rule (which he was wont to say, 〈◊〉 al the latin he would haue his sonne to learne,VVhat learning Levves the 11. required in his sonne. to wit, Qui nes • dissimulare, nescit regnare He which knoweth not how to disse •
ble, knoweth not how to raygne) might haue moued him 〈◊〉 haue doubted in his enemy, that which he practysed him self • and was apt enough to suspect in his best frinds. And this he ha • iust cause to feare in the Duke of Burgundy, whome he had dece •
ued before by a false composition, which he made with him 〈◊〉
Constans, & brake presently after, wherby he had both incited & also taught him, to paye him with money of the same stam • Wherein may be noted as wel his notable error, as also Go • prouidence and iustice in punishing his double dealing with t •• like, according to the saying of our Sauiour; Qua mensura, & • VVhat measure you shal make or giue to others,
Matt. 7. the same shal be measure • or made to you againe.

4. No lesse notable an example both of the one and of th • other, may be obserued in Caesar Borgia duke of Valence, who •• great wisdome Machiauel so much admireth,Machia. princ. Caesar Borgia Du • of Valence the paterne of machiauels prince: ouerthrovvne by h s ovvne policy. that he maketh hi • a mirrour and paterne for a prince; whome he might mo •• iustly haue made a mirrour of mischeife, and paterne of al perfidiousnes, cruelty and impiety. This Caesar being after the deat • of his father spoyled of al the estates that he had by force an • fraud layed to geather in Italy, and in danger as he thought o •
his life, or libertie at least,Guicciat. hist. lib. 6. by the displeasure of Pope Iulius the se
• ond that then raigned, resolued to flie for his securitie to Har
• ando Goncales, general in the kingdome of Naples, for Ferdinando
• ing of Aragon and Castile; forgetting, or not considering, the • anifold causes of offence that he had giuen to him, and to the • ing his maister in sundry occasions, and so trusting to his safe • onduict, he put him selfe into his handes, and was shor • ly after • ent by him prisoner into Spayne, by order from the King; • hereof Goncales excused him selfe, pretending that his faith and •• fe conduit, ought not to hinder his execution of the King • as maisters commandement, against whome he said he could • iue no securitie: and so the Arch-politike of his time, who had • y subti • it • & treachery, ouerthrowne very many, was him selfe • y God iust iu • gment ouer-reached, and (as I may tearme it) ••• ipt in his owne play, to his vtter ruine and ouerthrow, as vpon • n other occasion shalbe declared more amply hereafter.

5. Therfore what was become of al his accustomed craft? • here were al those profound policies, that excellent iudg
• ēt, that sharpnes of wit,Hovv farre a man may trust a reconciled enemie. those rare inuentions that made him • uch a worthy patern of Machiauels prince? for whether we res
• ect true wisdome, or the common craft and subtilitie of world
•• e men (which is now commonly called machiauillian policie) • e erred in the principles of both; for subtilitie and craft, which • xcludeth al charitie, teacheth so to distrust, as neuer to trust, • or to pardon an enemie, nor to leaue to hate, hurt, & reuenge, • hen oportunity is offered, notwithstanding any reconciliation. Besides that, the mallice of men so farre extendeth it selfe in • uch cases, that politikes hold it not secure for him that doth offend any man, to trust him euer after. To which purpose the • talian prouerbe saith. Chi offende non perdona mai, whereby it is signified, that he which doth any notable iniurie to an other man, can neuer after with his owne saftie trust him, or yet spare • im if he may ouerthrow him, for feare that at some time or other he may seke to be reuenged; so that this Arch-politike according to the rules of his owne art and profession, should haue neuer put his life into the hands of one whome he had once offended, and much lesse of an open enemie reconciled.

6. And as for true wisdome though it euer keepe it selfe
within the boundes of charitie, and teacheth vs not only 〈◊〉 p ••
don, but also to loue our enemies, yea and to doe them 〈◊〉 pleasure we conueniently may; yet it so ioineth the pruden •
〈◊〉 the serpent, with the simplicity of the doue, that it warneth vs to b •
ware of them, Seneca. A reconciled enemie not to be trusted. Ecclesiast. 12. and not to trust our liues or states in their hand • when we may auoid it, remembring euer the councel of Se ••••
who saith. Neuer beleeue that he wil be faithful vnto thee, who of 〈◊〉 enemie is become thy friend. Which also the Holy Ghost teacheth i • the booke of Ecclesiasticus; where it is said. Neuer beleeue or tr ••• thy enemy, for as old Iron groweth euery day more rusty then other; so i •
creaseth his rancor; and if he humble him selfe, and crouch vnto thee, y •• haue an eye vnto him, and keepe thy selfe from him; place him not 〈◊〉 vnto thee, least he put thee out of thy place, and make thee know to thy c ••• how true are my wordes. And againe to the same purpose, Salom ••
saith in his parables. Prouerb. 26. VVhen thy enemy shal speake softly vnto thee (th •• is to say) shal flatter thee or speak thee faire, then trust him not, 〈◊〉 then his hart is ful of mischief. In al which the Holy Ghost instr •
cteth, and aduiseth vs to be warie, but not malicious; to be ci •
cumspect, but not suspitious; to haue an eye to a reconcile • enemie, but not to hate or hurt him, or to reuenge old wronge • Therefore Salomon coūterpe vseth the foresaid doctrin with pr •
ceptes of compassion, & charity towardes our enemies, sayin •
VVhen they enemy falleth,
Prouerb: 24. be not glad therof, and let not thy hart reioyce 〈◊〉 his ruyn, least our Lord seinge it, be displeased with thee, and turne 〈◊〉 wrath from him.
Prouerb: 25. And in an other place; if thy enemie (saith he) 〈◊〉
hungry, g • ue him meat, if he be thirsty giue him drinke, and thou sh •• cast coales vpon his head, and our Lord shal reward thee, Thus far th • kinge and prophet, Rom. 12. whose wordes S. Paul also reciteth, and o • Sauiour confirmeth by his commandement; saying; Loue yo •• enemies, and doe good to them which hate you. &c.

7. Thus then we see how true wisdome, and Christian ch •
rity concurre, and how the prudence of the serpent, is to be ioyned with the simplicity of the doue,In vvhat manner vve may distrust our enemies. in so distrusting our enemies that we leaue not to loue them, and yet louing them s • that we trust them no further then may stand with our ow • safeti • , euer fearing the malice of mans nature, which is so abstruse a • d hidden, that no man can be assured of his best fren • and much lesse of a reconciled enemie. In which respect, it i •
wisdome so to loue and trust our friendes that we remember •• thal, that they may become our enemies;Seneca. ep. 3. And therefore Seneca
•• uiseth vs so to liue, that our actions may be as iustifiable • fore our frends as before our enemies. To which purpose • o the Holy Ghost in the booke of Ecclesiastes saith: Ab ini
• cis tuis seperare, & ab amicis tuis attende. Eccles. 6. Seperate thy selfe from • y enemies, and beware euen of thy frends. And in an other •• ce; A filijs tuis & domesticis attende. Eccles. 32. Take heede of thy owne •• ildren, and of thy how should seruants; which neuerthelesse not to be vnderstood, as though a man should trust no bodie, • hich were not only a miserable case, but also extreme folly. •• r as Seneca saith. It is as foule a fault, and as great a folly in a man, to • eue and trust no body, as to beleeue and trust euery man: and many,
Seneca. ep. 5. No lesse folly to distrust al men then to trust euery man. Plut: in Dion.
•• th he, whiles they feare to be deceaued, do teach men to deceaue them, •• ging them iustly there vnto, by suspecting them wrongfully. The which
••• tark also confirmeth saying; That fooles for lack of wit to prouide • erwayes for their owne securitie, doe thinke it the safest and wisest •• y to distrust al men, and so in the end they procure their owne ruine.

8. Therefore in this point of confidence, and diffidence •• e wisdome consisteth (as al vertue doth) in the meane, to wit, •• at we nether trust, nor distrust al men,Hovv distrust may be called the mother of security. nether commit our ••• es and whole estate to any mans wil and pleasure, but only in • e of necessitie, and then also to make discreete choyce of ap
•• oued, wise, and vertuous friends, but neuer of a reconciled •• emie. And in this sence it is wel and wisely said; that Diffiden
• est mater secu • itatis; Distrust is the mother of security.

9.Hovv distrust and suspicion may stand vvith true prudence and charitie. Cor. 13. Chrisost: hom. 33. in. 1. Cor. 13. But now perhaps you wil aske me how the rule of perfect • aritie, and of true prudence can agree herein, seeing charity as Paul saith: non cogitat malum; doth not thinke any euil, that is 〈◊〉 say (as S. Chrisostome expoundeth it) suspecteth no euil; how •• en can I distrust my reconciled enemie, but I must suspect •• at he wil betray me? Whereto I answere, that two thinges are 〈◊〉 be considered in charitie, the one that it beginneth at a mans •• fe, for no man is bound so to loue an other, that he hurt him •• fe: the other is, that as S. Paul testifieth also of charitie,1. Cor. 13. non • it perperam: it doth nothing foolishly or vnaduisedlie. For 〈◊〉
S. Chrisostome saith, expounding the same place, Charitas non • t temeraria, &c: Charitie is not rash and headie, for it maketh
a man wise, graue, and constant.

10. Now then to shew how suspition is excluded from t •• prudent circumspection, which charitie admitteth, it is to 〈◊〉 vnderstood,Hovv suspition is excluded from prudent circumspection. that I may be warie and circumspect, though I 〈◊〉 not suspect, but only vpon a general supposition of mans or ••
narie frailty and malice, and the inscrutabillity of his hart, I 〈◊〉 in a doubtful case take the surest way, to wit, that although, verely hope that my reconciled enemie be so good, and ho • a man, that there resteth no malice in his hart towardes me • neuerthelesse I wil be so considerat and prouident, that put t •• case he should haue the wil to hurt me, yet he shal not haue t •• opportunitie or occasion to doe it by any act of mine: in whi •• sence our english prouerbe may be wel vnderstood, which sai ••
If my freend betray me, I beshrew him; but if my enemie betray me, I besh ••• my selfe. And this aduised and warie proceeding is so far fro • breach of charitie, that it standeth wel with al kind of loue 〈◊〉 frendshippe, betwixt frind and frind, father, and child, brot ••• and brother, man and wife, prince and subiect. And therfore respect that it seemeth to include some kind of suspition, 〈◊〉 withal admitteth al charitable affection it is called by some, Be ••
uola suspitio, a frendly or louing suspition: in which sense S. C •••
sostome saith.Chrisost. hom. de S. Susanna. Maleuola suspitiones sunt calumniantium; beneuola s ••
pitiones sunt gubernantium; Malitious suspitions are proper to C •
lumniatours; beneuolous, and frendly suspitions belong to G •
uernours.

11. Therefore to returne to duke Valentin, hereby we may 〈◊〉 that he was destitute, not only of true wisdome, but also of wit, and reasonable discourse, when he, in whose handes, 〈◊〉 brother or frend could euer be secure, expected securitie in 〈◊〉 hands of his enemie, and perswaded him selfe, that faith sho ••• be kept with him, who had neuer kept it with any man. But ••
cause I shal haue more occasion to • peake of him hereafter, I 〈◊〉 passe to a moderne example of mans ignorance and weaknes, 〈◊〉 the miserable end of Monsieur Chastillon, Monsieur Chastillion. Admiral 〈◊〉 France fought his owne destruction. Admiral of France 〈◊〉 sacred at Paris, who for the great opinion of his wisdome 〈◊〉 prudence, had the conduct of al the affaires of the Protesta •• in France, some yeeres in the first troubles in the time of Ki ••
Charles the 9.

12. when after some yeares of cruel warre in France betwixt •• e Catholikes, and the Protestants, peace was concluded in the •• are 1570. & for the better assurance thereof, a mariage agreed •• on betwixt the most Christian King that now raygneth, •• en called King of Nauare, and the sister of Charles the 9. •• en King of France, al the cheife heads, and leaders of the Pro
•• stants, were inuited by the King to the court, aswel for the ••• emnization of the mariage,The massaker of Protestants at Paris an. 1570. as for the confirmation of the • ace, whereupon there was held an assembly of the Protestants Rochel, to determine whether it were conuenient that they • ould al goe to the court or no, and it seeming good vnto them •• at some of the principal, especially the Admiral should stay at •• me to preuent the worst, in case there should be any double •• aling on the Kinges part, the Admiral only was of opinion that was conueniēt they al, & especially he him selfe should goe, & • eaged many reasons to that purpose; and finding them neuer
•• elesse vnwilling therto the put them in mind how oft he had •• alded to them, contrary to his owne opinion in diuers con
••• tations, and therfore requested them, that in this they would •• ndescend vnto him, not doubting but it would turne to the •• blike benifit of their cause. Wel, to be breife, they yealded •• to him, rather to satisfie his importunity, then for any liking •• ey had therto, and so he went with the rest, and within a few •• yes after their arriual at Paris, both he and they al (excepting •• me two or three that escaped by chance) were slayne, by order 〈◊〉 the King

13. Who seeth not here an euident example of mans igno
•• nce & weaknes, in the Admiral, who hauing in so many occasi
•• s before this tyme of his ouerthrowe, shewed him selfe so •• udent and prouident, that he could nether be ouercome by •• rce, nor circumuented by fraud had not now so much wit,The errour of the Admiral of France.
〈◊〉 to follow the wise aduise of o • hers, but thought it safe and ••• cure for him and them, to aduenture (as a man may say) al their •• ods in one bottome, yea and without any necessity to put •• em selues to the mercy of a Soueraine King whome they had 〈◊〉 highly and so many wayes offended. And this may be the more • ondered at in the Admiral, Estien, Pasqui •• lib. 5. epist. for that in the beginning of the •• cond troubles, he wisely foresawe the like danger, and inconuenience
to him selfe, and warely auoided it. For, the 〈◊〉 hauing got some inkling of the Protestants intention to 〈◊〉 new broiles, and fearinge most the Admiral in respect of 〈◊〉 great iudgement and experience, both in matter of warre 〈◊〉 peace, sent vnto him Monsieur du Tore his cosen to adur • him that he had great and important affaires to communi ••• with him, wherein he would gladly haue his aduise, and the ••
fore desired him to repaire to the court with speede; The A •
miral hearing the message and suspecting (as it should seeme that the King ment no good towardes him, said to Monsieur 〈◊〉 Tore, The ansvvere of the admirable of France to the King. that he should tel the King from him, that there were 〈◊〉
Count Egmonds in France; meaning that he wold not suffer his he • to be out of so easely as Count Egmond had done latelie before Flanders. And this was al the answere he would giue him; w ••••
by it appeareth how circumspect he was and suspicious of 〈◊〉 King, when as yet he had giuen him fatre lesse cause of offe • then afterwardes when he had the second time rebelled ag •••• him yea and forced him to make a dishonorable peace, and 〈◊〉 notwithstanding he could not be disswaded from putting h •• selfe and al the rest of his frends into his hands;The first blovv that God giueth a vvicked man, vvhen he vvil destroy him, is in the brayn. so blind is 〈◊〉 wit and iudgement of man, when God determineth to punish him, for then the first blowe that God commonlie giueth him, is in the braine, wherby he taketh from him his iudgement, that he may runne headlong vpon his owne ruine, Psal. 9. and as the Psalmist saith of the sinner, be ouer reached in his owne plots and inuentions.

div.head: • Y OCCASION OF THE FORMER EXAMples, it is debated in the next chapter, vvhether the Emperour Charles the 5. did prudently in passing through France, vpon a safe conduict; and of the danger he vvas in, and hovv he escaped. Also the error of Henry the 3. King of France, in the slaughter of the Duke of Guise and the Cardinal. CHAP. 4.
div.p:
IT shal not be amisse to consider here,The passage of Charles the fifth through France into Flanders. Surius in commentario rerum in orbe gestarum anno. 1539. by the occasion of these examples, whether the most valiant, prudent, and pious Emperour Charles the 5. commited an error or no, when after many yeares warre, betwixt him, and Francis the first of that name King of France, and the sayd •• ings disgrace at Pauia, and his imprisonment in Spaine, he passed • otwithstādinge through France vpon a safe conduict giuen him 〈◊〉 the King, to giue remedy to the tumultes lately before raysed 〈◊〉
Gant: wherein the good successe, aswel of his safe passage as of • e speedie pacification of those troubles, may seeme to be no • ale argument of his prudēnt designment; neuerthelesse waigh
•• g the matter according to reason of state, & not according to •• e successe (which depending wholie on the hand of God is • any tymes good & fortunate, though the councel and design
• ent be imprudent) I can not approue his resolution therin, for •• e reasons aboue declared, and the extreme danger that he ex
• osed him selfe vnto, and the smale profit he could expect to • eape therby, incomparison of the dammage that might haue • ucceded to him and his estate, if he had bene made away, or • etained. For although it imported him very much, presently to • uench that fire kindled in Flanders, before it should growe to 〈◊〉 greater combustion; yet the danger therof was not so great, as • ould haue bene in the inconuenience of his death or imprison
• ent, if it should haue chanced.

2. For; the reuolte of the coūtry might haue bene remedied
ether by force, or perhaps by faire meanes, as longe as he 〈◊〉 life and liberty: but the other had bene remediles; and the gr ••
test detriment that could befalle him; & therfore not to be ••
uentured vpon, but only when it could not be auoyded 〈◊〉 this no doubt, was his owne opinion when he came into 〈◊〉 being admonished of his great danger, not only by his sister th •
Queene of France, but also (as some men thinke) by the Kin • owne sonne the Dolphin, The dangers that Charles the 5. escaped in pasing through France. Surius ibidem. who in respect of the good affection 〈◊〉 did beare him, from the time that he had bene hostage for 〈◊〉 father in Spaine, cast him selfe vp behind the Emperour vpon 〈◊〉 horse, at his first arriualle before he alight (vnder couler to gi •• him a familiar welcome) & clapt him vpon the shoulder, sayi •• vnto him openly and merily, Yealde thy selfe Emperour; but af ••• tould him secretly in his eare of the councells resolution to 〈◊〉 him, whereupon the Emperour thinking it necessary to ga ••
Madame d' Estampes (who was greatly fauored by the King, 〈◊〉 thought to be his enemy) tooke occasion as he was talki •• with her, to let falle before her a rich diamond as it were 〈◊〉 chance, and when she of curtesy tooke it vp to restore it vn •• him, he would not receaue it againe at her handes, but intre •
ted her to accept it as his gift, whereby (as also by his go • perswasions) it is thought he procured her frendshippe, whi •• cōcurring with the indeauours of his sister the Queene of Fran ••
and his owne good diligences done with diuers of the Counc •• was thought to facilitate his escape.

3. But who, or whatsoeuer was the meanes therof, it is 〈◊〉 to be doubted, but that it proceeded principally from the pro ••
dence and mercy of almighty God towardes him. To whi •• purpose it is to be considered, that it was reported not only 〈◊〉 his owne seruantes, but also by the Embasadours of Flanders th • attēded vpon him in al that iourney, that he spent 2. or 3. how • euery night in praier vpon his knees, Surius ibid. The great deuotion of Charles the fifth. & asmuch euery morni •• secretely in his chamber: in regard whereof, and of the gre •• seruice he had done, and was to doe to Gods Church, it may 〈◊〉 presumed that God did specially fauour & protect him, wher •
of it pleased his Diuine majesty also to giue publicke testimon • by deliuering him twise whiles he was in France from euide •• danger of death; the one time from stifeling in a smoake, th ••
vpon a suddaine was raised in great aboundance by an arteficial ••• e, vpon a steare, as he was going from his chamber,Idem. Ibid. and an • ther time from the fal of a great borde that light some part of it • pon his head and brake it. And although it might haue bene •••• eaued that these thinges proceeded of some practice (in • hich respect the King would haue punished the authors therof 〈◊〉 death, for the better satisfaction of the Emperour) yet he • ould not suffer it, but obteined their pardons.

4. By these dangers, & the happie escape of the Emperour (in
•• riour in wisdome to no prince in his time) three things may e
•• dently be gathered. The first, his error: the second, th'in firmity • nd weaknes of mans wit: the third, Gods most merciful and • rouident care in the preseruation of his seruantes,VVhy God suffereth his seruants to fal into dangers. whome he •• ffereth some time to erre and to fal into great dangers and dif
•• culties; partely for their humiliation, and to exercise their • ith, patience, and confidence in him, for their greater merit; •• d partly to make manifest aswel to them selues as to al others, •• e louing care he hath of them, and that as the Psalmist saith;
• lus iustorum à Domino, & protector eorum in tempore tribulationis.
Psal: 36.
• he health and saluation of iust men, is from our Lord, and he is • heir protector in the time of trouble. Here then may al Princes • earne of this prudent and pious Emperour, what is their best • emedie in like cases of danger, to wit, to haue recourse, as he • ad, to almighty God, and to craue his assistance, reposing them • elues alwaies vpon his merciful prouidence, and saying with • he worthy King and Prophet. Oculi mei semper ad Dominum,
Psal; 24. quo
• iam ipse euellet de laqueo pedes meos, that is to say; My eies are alwayes • pon our Lord, for he wil deliuer my feete from the snare.

5. I might adde to the errors in this kinde,The errour of Henry the third of France, in the slaugther of the Duke & Cardinal of Guise anno. 1588. diuers other ex
• mples, notorious in this age, but I omit them for breuityes • ake, to speake a word or two of Henrie the 3. King of France, and • f his error and want of iudgment in the slaughter of the Duke, • nd the Cardinal of Guise, whereof I am able to say much of my • wne knowledge, for that I was at the same time in his courte • nd pallace at Blays in the seruice of his mother; and wondered • ot a litle to see & heare, many that were acompted very wisemen, applaud to the Kinges act, as most prudent and necessarie, • n so much that when any man vrged that it was against conscience
to kil them in that manner especially the Cardinal,
〈…〉 commonly answered, That reason of state required it. Which 〈◊〉 moued me to thinke euen then vpon writing some disco ••• concerning the necessarie concurrance of the reason of 〈◊〉 with conscience and religion, though I haue not had oppo •••
nitie to performe it vntil now.

6. Neuertheles leauinge apart the consideration whe •• the act was in it selfe lawful or no, and weighing the circ ••
stances therof,The great affection of the people of France to the duke of Guise and the Cardinal. only according reason of state; I thinke no 〈◊〉 wil denie, that the King knowing the auersion, and aliena •••• of his people from him selfe, their exceedinge great affection 〈◊〉 the Duke of Guise & to al the princes of his family, and the c ••
federacie of al the principal townes of France with them; y •• and with the Pope and the Catholike King (for the defence of C •
tholike Religion, in respect of the fauor that the King of Fra ••• had shewed to the Protestants both at home and abroad) 〈◊〉 man (I say) wil denie, but that he should in al reason haue s •
ficiently prouided him selfe of money and forces, before he ••
solued to kil the Duke, & especially the Cardinal, in such an odio •• manner as he did, whereby he was sure to incurre the censu •• of the Church, and thereby to giue a sufficient pretext to 〈◊〉 owne subiects to take armes against him, and to forreine Princ •• to assist them.

7. But he was at that time so vnprouided of al meanes, to r •
presse the fury of his enemies, & to defend him selfe, that a pr ••
cipal man about him, who at the first did greatly approue his 〈◊〉 tould me within a few daies after, that he had greatly ouers ••• him selfe, in doing it at such a time, when he had nether 〈◊〉 principal towne at his commandment, nor forces in the feil •• nor money in his purse: which was indeed most true, as I 〈◊〉 testifie vpon my owne knowledge. For as for the townes, 〈◊〉 of the cheife and next vnto him,The reuolt of the principal tovvnes of France against Henrie the third. to wit, Orleance whereof he 〈◊〉 counted him selfe most sure (by reason that the gouerno • therof was wholy at his deuotion & the Citadel in his hand) 〈◊〉 the very first that declared it selfe against him, within lesse th • 2. daies after the act; the example wherof, Paris, Roane, and al t ••
Parlamental, and other principal townes presently followed, in 〈◊〉 much that there neuer passed 3. or 4. daies but there was new •
of the reuolt of some one great towne or other; whereupon en
•• ed so great necessitie and pouerty, not only to the King, but • o to al the nobility in his court, that I thinke the like hath sel
•• me bin seene in the court of any prince. For the townes sea
•• g presently, & intercepting in their iurisdiction al the kinges • ts, and receits, and the goods and reuenewes of al such as • ere with him, reduced them to such necessitie, that they were ••• ced to coyne their plate into money, and yet neuerthelesse • thin a while they had not wherewith to buy them selues • ate; In so much that the greatest and richest prince of France, • s forced to borrow of one of his owne Chaplins al the money 〈◊〉 had, which was but 30.The great misery and necessitie of the King of France, and al his court. crownes as the preist him selfe tould 〈◊〉 ) and the Queene was constrained to send away almost al her •• dies, and maides: (who in respect they were women were •• fered by the townes to passe) and the King for his parte was • bate of money, as I vnderstood by one of his treasures who • s my great freend, that for the remedie of his necessitie, and furnish the expence of his remoue to Tours (whither he was ••• ced to flie) he had no other meanes but to make three new ••• icers, vpon cōdition to prouide him amongst them 30. thou
••• d crownes, which was al the stock and store he had for that ••• sent, to susteine the waight of so great a warre, as he had by 〈◊〉 owne ouersight drawne vpon him selfe.

• . And for his forces, it appeared presently how weake they • re, for al his guardes and such other souldiers as he then had •• die, or could leauie in 2. or 3. monethes space, being sent to
••• eance to assist the Cittadel (which held for him against the • wne) were so few in number, that vpon the first newes of Mon
•• r du M • yenes march thitherward with no more then 3. or 4. •• ousand men, they abandoned the Cittadel; yea and the King •• m selfe was faine to flye downe the riuer in al hast to Tours, Henry the 3. of France his confederacy vvith the Protestants and the successe therof.
• ere after some time he was forced (for want of other remedy) 〈◊〉 take the resolution to ioine with the Protestants, which •• ough it increased his forces, for the present, yet it so redou
•• ed the hatred and fury of his enemies, that it did accelerate 〈◊〉 distruction, which shortly followed, as I shal haue occasion 〈◊〉 declare more particulerly other where.

9. Herein thou maiest obserue (good Reader) how this great
King (who in cunning subtility and al Machiauillian policy 〈◊〉 inferior to none in this age) erred neuertheles most absurd •• that which a man would now thinke a child would hardly 〈◊〉 bene deceaued in; so easelie is an error seene when it is past, 〈◊〉 so hard to be foreseene, and preuented, especially where p ••• reigneth, from the which very few men, or none are free in ••
ters that touch them selues. But because I shal haue occas ••• to speake also hereafter of other errors of particuler men, I 〈◊〉 ad to the former some examples of the errors of whole Coun ••• and Senates.

div.head: OF ERRORS COMMITTED BY VVHO •• Senats, namely of Rome, and Venice, vvith the conclus ••• of the premisses; and an admonition to the Politikes, concern ••• their folly and ingratitude tovvards almighty God. CHAP. 5.
div.p:
WHAT marueile is it that particuler men, 〈◊〉 they neuer so wise, be ouerseene in matters state, seeing that the most wise and gra •• Senats haue also erred therein many time • whereof I wil for breuities sake, allea ••• only 3. or 4. examples. Cicero reporteth that Senat of Rome hauing taken great sommes of money of certa •• tributarie citties to make them free,An errour of the Senate of Rome. forced them after to 〈◊〉 their old tribute without restoring to them the money that t •• had paied for their freedome,Cicero li. 3 de officijs. which he saith was; Turpe impe •
A shame to their empire; Piratarum enim (saith he) melior f ••• des, quam senatus; For the faith of pirats, was better then the Fa ••• of the Senat.

2. This then being so great a fraude that in any wel gou ••
ned commonwelth it could not passe vnpunished in priu ••• men, must needes be a foule and shameful fault in a whole S •
nate, not only for the iniustice of the fact, but also for the en • they committed in gouernment, to wit, in giuing to their s ••
iects
an example of fraudulent, and deceitful dealinge, which •• ing, as it were, authorised by their publike act, would the •• re easely insinuate it selfe into the cōmonwelth, to the great ••• riment therof. To which purpose Cicero saith;Cicero. lib. 3. de legibus. Princes and go
•••• ors, when they offend, doe not only endammage the commonwelth, in ••• t they are corrupted them selues, but also in that they corrupt others, and 〈◊〉 more by their euil example, then by the offence it selfe.

3. Seeing then nothinge can be more pernicious to any state •• en that fraud and iniustice should haue course therin) for, as
••• ero saith Faith is the foundation of iustice, Cicero: office. lib. 1. & 2. and iustice the stay of ••• te) the Romane Senate did erre most absurdly in opening the ••• e to al kind of cosenage in the commonwelth by their owne ••• mple, besides the losse of reputation which must needes fol
•• w therof to their empyre, as wel with their owne subiects, also with their friendes and confederates; a thinge so dange
•• us to state, that the same Senat informer tymes, being better •• uised, Restitution made by the Senate of Rome, to the Ardeatines. T. Liuius. Dec. 1. li. 4. Idem. Dec. 1. li. 3. did make restitution and reparation of like wronges to •• couer their credit with their confederates and freends, and •• erfore they restored to the Ardeatins, a peece of land which the •• ople of Rome had against al reason and equity adiudged and •• ken to them selues some yeares before, when the said Ar
••• tins, and the Aricinians being in controuersie for that land, •• d remitted them selues and their cause to their iudgment.

4. Likewise at other tymes the Senate resolued to deliuer • ost notable men, to their enemyes,The great care the Romans had of their credit and reputation. rather then to infringe iu
••• ce, and incurre the infamy of fraude, and deceite; In which •• spect, T. Verturius, and Spurius Posthumus both of them Consulls •• d T. Mutius, and Quintus Aemilius tribunes of the people, were •• liuered prisoners to the Samnites, Cicero. li. 3. de officijs. rather then the Senat would ••• tify the peace they had made with them; Besides that the fa
• ous Consul, M. Attilius Regulus being taken prisoner in Africke dismissed vpon condition that the prisoners of the Carthagi
• ns should be also deliuered, was by his owne motion sent •• ck by the Senat, because they nether thought good, to de
••• er the prisoners, nor yet to lose their credit, and reputation 〈◊〉 iustice, by recouery of their Consul, contrary to the con
•• tion.

5. But perhaps you wil say that the error which I here reproue,
was cōmitted when the commonwelth was g 〈7 letters〉 corruption, and declyned from the integrytie of vert ••
〈◊〉 iustice wherein it flourished in former tymes; therfore 〈◊〉 consider the same commonwelth in her purity, I meane in 〈◊〉 beginning aboute 120. yeares after the expulsion of the Ki •• For although the Senat did at that tyme giue many notable ••
amples of singuler prudence and exact iustice; yet it failed s •• times in both, to the great dammage of the state.

An other errour of the Roman Senate.6. When Brennus the Brittaine (as some say) being Capta •• of the Gaules that pasted into Italie, beseiged a towne ca ••
Clusium, beyond the Alpes, and demanded of the inhabita •• some parte of their territorie; the Clusians finding them sel •• to weake to resist them,The seige of Clusium by the Gaules. craued succour of the Romans, who 〈◊〉 Embassadors to treat peaceably with the Gaules in their beha •• during which treatie and seige, there chanced to passe some 〈◊〉 of hostilitie betwixt the Gaules & the Clusians, wherein the G •••••
perceiued that the Roman Embassadours contrarie to the law 〈◊〉 armes, had borne armes against them, and killed a princi ••• personage of theirs; whereupon they presently sent to R ••••
to require the Romanes to punish their Embassadours for re ••
ration of the wronge which they had done them; But the Se •
tours although (as Liuy confesseth) they knew wel enough t •• the Gaules demanded no more then was reasonable,T. Liuius Dec. 1. li. 5. y • they were partly so partial in the behalfe of their Embassado •• and partly so confident of their owne forces, that they not o • refused to doe them iustice, but also made the same Embassad •• Generals of an armie to be sent to succour the Clusians. Vpon 〈◊〉 knowledge whereof the Gaules were incensed with such fu •• that calling God and man to witnes of the wrong, they prese ••
ly raised their seige from Clusium, and went directly in al ha ••
Rome, Rome sacked and spoyled by the Gaules. and by the way ouerthrew the armie of the Romanes, en ••• the cittie, sacked, spoiled, and burnt it, with the greatest da •
mage & disgrace to their state, that euer the Romans receiued 〈◊〉 the space of aboue 1100. yeares after that Rome was built, I me •• vntil the first sack thereof by the Goths.

7. The which may be ascribed partely to Gods iust iudgme •• in punishing their iniustice, & partely to their error, in that 〈◊〉 to much contemned so huge an armie of so valiant people, a •
〈◊〉
exasperate them by open iniuries, & to drawe them vpon them •• lues with redoubled fury, whereas they should in al reason of •• te, haue sought to pacifye and diuert them by al conuenient • eanes, considering that he is not wise that feareth not the •• ubtful euents of warre, especially at home, where the victory 〈◊〉 an enemy is most dangerours, and in this case most of al, where •• e whole state was to be aduentured against an outragious mul
•• tude of desperat vagabonds that had nothing to loose; so that •• is error was no lesse costly to the commonwelth, then inexcu
•• ble in the Senate.

8. Hereto I might ad diuers examples, of the Senat of Venice to •• e which Guicciaidin saith,Guicciard: hist li. 4. It is fatal some yeeres to be deceaued diuers •• nes. But two examples shal suffice, the first may be their reso
•• tion to make league with Lewis the 12. King of France, to assist •• m in the conquest of Milane against Lodouicus Sforza Duke •• ereof, following the opinion of Antonius Grimanni, Ibid. li. 4. hist. which Guic
••• rdin saith proceeded partly of passion, and partly of a desire to 〈◊〉 large their dominions, by ioyning Cremona to the rest of their ••• tes in Italy,The errour of the Venetians in making league vvith Levvis the 12. of France. notwithstanding that Marchio Treuisano had dis
• aded the same with most strong and pregnant reasons, repre
•• nting vnto them by examples then fresh in memory, how dan
•• rous it would be for them, to bring the French into Italy, and 〈◊〉 haue so potent a neighbour in the state of Miliane as a King of •• ance, whereof they saw the effect shortly after, when King
•• wis had it in his possession; For then were they in such feare 〈◊〉 his forces, that they durst deny him nothing that he deman
• ed of them, as Guicciardin noteth,Guicciard. li. 4. in fine. in their deliuering of Cardinal • scanius brother to duke Lodouicus, and of Baptista viscount and •• uers other noble men of Milane who had put them selues into •• eir protection, vpon their publike safe conduict, with expresse • ention of safeguard against the French.

9. An other error of theirs more dangerous, and damma
• ble vnto them then the former; was, their great ouersight, as
• el in their vnaduised proceedinges towardes their confederate •• d freend Francis the first of that name King of France,
Guicciard. li. 8. initio. The erour of the Venetian in ioyning vvith K. Francis of France. as also in •• e iniuries which they did to the Pope, & the Emperour Maximi
•• an, wherby they draue them al, that before were diuided, to •• ite them selues with the King of Castile and diuers other princes
against them in the league of Cambray.

fused it, by the perswasion of Dominicus Treuisano Procurator 〈◊〉
S. Marks, though other of the grauest and wisest Senatours
〈◊〉 of contrary opinion: Therfore the issue of the matter w •• that al these princes ioyning their forces togeather accordi •• to their agrement, spoyled them of al their possessions in Ital • and deuided the same amongst them selues, and had prosecut •• their victory further, if the Pope had not bene a mediator 〈◊〉 them, and procured their peace vpon their humble submission 〈◊〉 the Emperour, whome they most wronged.

10. Seing then these famous and renowned Senates consisti •• of so many wise and graue men,A consideration of mans imbecillity, and weaknes of vvit, and of the need he hath of Gods direction. haue committed so grosse err ••• to their owne great preiudice, and danger of their state; w ••• assurance can any man haue of mans wit, plots, & defygnme •• if he confide either in him selfe alone, or in the only coun •• and iudgment of man. And therfore considering what I ha •• here before discoursed concerning the condition and state 〈◊〉 man, his natural subiection, seruitude, and bondage, to his L •• God and Creator, his dependance vpon his holy wil and pr •
uidence, his frailty and imbecillity, his blindnes of wit, 〈◊〉 weaknes of iudgement, his frequent errors, be he neuer so wis • and lastly his necessity in respect of al this, to craue, and ha •• his Lord and Creators assistance, direction, and protection; h ••• vngratful and simple are those men that presume so far of the •• owne wits and sufficiency, that nether for their priuate, nor 〈◊〉 publike affayres, they make any account of Gods healp or ••
sistance?The ingratitude of such as do not acknovvledge the bounty of God tovvards them. vngratful (I say) for that hauing good partes and ••
lents, and many temporal blessinges, which nature and rea ••• teacheth them not to be (as I haue said before) of their o •• purchase and prouision, but of the liberality and bounty 〈◊〉
••
mighty God, they doe neuertheles so admire the gift, that th •• forget the giuer, and so enioy the benefit, that they doe not 〈◊〉 much as thanke him that bestowed it vpon them; yea and 〈◊〉 steede of thankes, prayse, honor and seruice which they o •• him, doe render him contempt, dishonor, and disseruice.
