therfore no meruaile if almighty God, in punishment of so great •• gratitude, doe giue them ouer many times, to a reprobate •• se, to the end, that as they offend him by an ouerweening of •• eir owne wisdome, so they may be punished, yea and perrish 〈◊〉 their owne folly; This ingratitude of man,Aug. lib. Soliloq. S. Augustine wor
••• ly calleth; The roote of al spiritual euil, the drie and burninge wind ••• t blasteth al our corne, and stoppeth vp the fountaine of Gods mercie ••• ards vs.

11. But herein appeareth not only the ingratitude, but also •• e extreame folly of such men (be they accompted neuer so • se) seeing that their weaknes and imbecillitie is so manifest • uen to them selues if they list to consider it) that they may ea
••• y perceaue that they are not absolute of them selues,The extreame folly of such as trust vvholy in them selues. but that •• ey depend vpon a higher power, and yet neuertheles they are vnaduised, as to cast them selues into the innumerable dāgers, •• d difficulties of this world without regard, yea with contempt •• d offence of him, on whome they depend, and who only can •••• ect, and guide them aright; wherein they may be compared to me simple & self-willed fellow, that wil needes put him selfe 〈◊〉 sea in a terrible tempest without a pilot, or vndertake a iorney •• rough a dangerous desert in a darke night, either without a • ide, or else hauing a deare and louing freend to guide him, • eth him so vnkindly, and contemptuously by the waie, that 〈◊〉 forceth him to forsake him in the midst of the wildernes, •• d so perisheth worthily through his owne follie, and in
•• atitude.

• 2. Therefore I conclude with this notable sentence of S. Au
••• tin, speaking to man. Thou receauest (saith he) the benefit,Aug. li. 4. meditat. doest not acknowledg th'author thereof; the gift is manifest & •• ough the giuer be hiden, yet thy owne reason may teach •• ee, that it is not thy due, but the gift of an other: And ther
•• re whosoeuer the geuer be, thou maist thinke, that as he hath •• stowed exceding much vpō thee; so he hath loued thee much, •• ing he would giue thee so much; And this being so,A notable discourse of S. Austen concerning the ingratitude of man tovvards God. what ex
•• eame folly is it, not to seeke and desier the loue of such a po
•• t and kind louer, and what peruerse ingratitude, and impiety • it, not to loue one that loues thee so exceedingly? If then thou •• e and esteeme his gifts, loue him that bestowed them vpon
thee, and loue them as thinges that are subiect to thee; an • thinges that should serue thee, as pledges of thy spowse, as g ••• of thy freend, as benefits of thy Lord; and so as thou maist 〈◊〉 be mindful how much thou art his debter, yea and loue his g ••• not for them selues, but for his sake, not togeather with 〈◊〉 but for him; & lastly loue them so, that thou maist loue him, 〈◊〉 them, and aboue them. Thus saith this famous and learned •
ther, which I wish al men would print in their hartes, and p ••
ctise in their workes, for so should their, councells and delibe ••
tions be more free from error, and their actions from il succe •• the which many times is not so properly the fruit of mans in •••
mitie, as a punishment of God for sinne, as it may appeare by 〈◊〉 examples alreadie alleaged, and shal more plainely hereafte • when I shal purposelie treate of Gods iustice.Chap. 16.17.18.19.20.21.22.

div.head: THE INSVFFICIENCY OF MANS VVIT • and policy, for the gouernment of commonwelth, is proued 〈◊〉 the nature of commonwelth, to vvit, by the natural mutabilli •• & instabillity therof, exemplified breifly in Empires, Kingdom • and other Estats. CHAP. 6.
div.p:
HItherto I haue laboured to shewe the insu ••
ciency of mans wit for the gouerment of co •
monwelth by the natural infirmitie of man now I wil proue the same by the nature commonwelth it selfe, which is a thinge mutable, so intricate, so ful of difficulties, subiect to accidents, vnpossible to be forseene and preuent • and hanging, as a man may say, vpon so many gymmols, that 〈◊〉 humane wit or power, is of it selfe able to assure & establish 〈◊〉

The natural mutabilitie and instabilitie of cōmonvvealth.2. For the proofe hereof, we are first to consider the natu •• mutabillity and instabillity of commonwelth, which consisti •• of men, must needes be subiect to the same mutation and co •
ruption, whereto al men and humane thinges are subiect, by 〈◊〉 inuiolable decree and law of God, the author of nature, w ••
hath irreuocably ordained, that whatsoeuer is compounded ei
•• er naturally of elements, or artificially by the industrie of men •• al be dissolued; and that whatsoeuer groweth and increaseth •• al decrease & perish. And therfore we see that al earthlie •• inges haue their beginning, their growth and increase, their • te and consistance, their declination and decay, & finally their •• ssolution. For besides infinite external causes by the which •• ey are sooner or later corrupted, and consumed, euery thinge • eedeth in it selfe an internal sicknesse, which in the end doth • euitably bring it to corruption. The Iron and other metalls, • eed a rust; the corne & other fruit, a worme; the cloath, a moth, • ens bodies and other liuing creatures, disseases which destroy •• em in the end, and so in like sort, commonwelth ingendreth it selfe, disorders, discord, and dissention, which sooner or la
•• r bring it to ruyne.

3. For the better explication hereof,The nature of commonvvelth. and of the nature of •• mmonwelth, it is further to be noted, that as the health and •• tegritie of euery thing that is compounded of different and ••• trary qualities, consisteth in the equal temperature of the said •• alities; so of the distemperature and inequality thereof, grow
•• h the corruption and dissolution of the said compound. For • here there is a continual conflict of contrarieties (euery one • orking according to his owne nature and propertie) it can not 〈◊〉 , but that in time one wil abound, and an other decay, one • eare and wast an other, and so in the end one ouercome, and •• tinguish th'other, whereby the composition must needes soo
• er or later be dissolued.

4. And this we see verified, not only in al natural bodies, • ompounded of contrarie humors, or elements (as in men, • easts, hearbes, trees, plants, and such like) but also in the poli
•• ke bodie, that is to say in commonwelth it selfe,VVherein and of vvhome a commonvvelth consisteth. consisting in • he combination of persons of different sexes, orders, degrees, • nd qualities; as of men, and women, prince and subiect, rich • nd poore, noble and base, bound and free, good and bad, and of • nnumerable particuler men, differing amongst them selues in • rofession of life, faculties, trades, and occupations, in manners • nd affections, and yet al vnited, and combined togeather in the • ommunion of one law, and gouernment. Wherefore euen as
mens bodies, being compact of contrary elements, and 〈◊〉 with different, and contrarie humors, are so much the 〈◊〉 healthful, sound, and durable, by how much the said hu •••• are better and more equallie tempered amongst them sel •• (which neuerthelesse can neuer haue such an exact and per • temperature, but that in time they wil consume one an oth •• and consequently destroie the bodie with the affect) euen so 〈◊〉 politike bodie, that is to say the commonwelth, is so much 〈◊〉 sounder, and florisheth the longer, by how much the tempe ••
ture of the different orders and degrees therein, is better, 〈◊〉 more equally composed.Plat. 8. de repub. Which temperature Plato calleth: 〈◊〉
harmonie consisting in an equal and concordant disparity, or inequali ••
wherwith the commonwealth is (as it were with a certai • bond) knit and vnited in it selfe.

5. But for asmuch as it is not possible, that the said polit ••• harmonie and consonance, can be for euer preserued in the co •
tinual discord and conflict of contrarie degrees, humors, incli ••
tions, affections and passions; it must needes follow that 〈◊〉 bond, that is to say, the harmony being interrupted and broke the cōmonwelth shal fal to disorder, and consequently deca •• As both Aristotle and Plato do teach,Arist: li. 5. Poli. ca. 12. Plato. de Rep. li. 80. and is also most manifest the experience of al ages and times, and of al kingdomes 〈◊〉 commonwelthes, either past, or present, as (to say somewh •• breefly of both) we see euidently in the ancient kingdomes 〈◊〉
Iuda, The desolation and ruine of many auncient kingdomes. and Israel, of Egipt, Macedony, Persia, Parthia, Lacedemony,
〈◊〉 in the commonwelth of the Carthaginians, Athenians, Corinthi ••• Thebans, and such others, al of them famous in times past, 〈◊〉 some of them florishing no lesse in al kind of learning and ••
mane wisdome, then in armes and militarie discipline, and n • vtterly perished;The often chāge of gouernment in the Roman Empire. Tit. liuius. in so much, that there is scant any monum ••• or memory of them. And hath not also the like chanced to 〈◊〉 mighty and potent empires of the Assirians, the Medes, the Gree •
and the Romans, whereof the last, which was also the mighty of the rest, had so many changes in a few ages, to wit in 6 • yeares space, that it receiued al formes and kindes of gouerme •• passing first from Kinges to Decemuiri, that it to say, ten goue •
nours: from the Decemuiri, to Kinges againe; from them to C ••
suls, from Consuls againe to Decemuiri, from them to the Tri •••••
of soldiars, from Tribunes to Consuls, from them to Perpetual Dicta
••• s, from Dictators to Triumuiri, and from them to Emperours, •• der whome the Empyre being miserably rent, and torne with •• il warrs, became in the end to be a pray and spoyle to al •• rbarous nations.

6. And if we looke to the kingdomes and commonwelthes •• ich stand on foote at this day, as namely our owne country,The diuers mutations in Britany since the Romans conquered it. Polidorus virgilius in hist. Angl.
•• d what changes and mutations there haue bene therin, since was first conquered by the Romans, how many kinges it hath •• d at once, to wit 7. how oft it hath bene conquered by stran
•• rs, as by Saxons, Danes and Normans; what ciuil warrs, and • ody battailes there haue bene since the last conquest, first in ••• g Stephens tyme, after in the Barrons warrs, and after againe •• twixt the howse of Lancaster and Yorke, for the space of aboue 〈◊〉 yeares, wherein we read that one only kinge, to wit, Edward
〈◊〉 4. was present and fought him selfe in 8. or 9.Philippus Commineus in hist. de reb. gest. Lodouici. c. 50. seueral bat
•• es, and that during the same tyme there were slayne & bani
•• ed 80. Princes of the blood royal. And againe if we add therto •• e depositions, expulsions, imprisonments, & murders of Kinges diuers ages, and tymes, and the frequent rebellions of the •• iects against their princes, for exactions, extortions, and in
•• uation of Religion. And if we also consider in Scotland, The reuolutions and diuisions in the Realmes of Scotland France Flanders, and other kingdomes adioyning. Ioan. Laesleus de Orig. Scot. Froysart. Poplinier. Froysart. Mercurius Belgicus. our •• xt neighbour, the like or rather greater reuolutions, which • e caused the violent or vntymely death and distruction of • r. 9. Kinges and regents, in these 2. last ages. And great mu
• ions and domestical diuisions which haue miserably distra
••• d, & almost ruined France, no lesse heretofore at diuers times, •• en now of late; As also the most frequent or rather conti
•• al commotions in Flanders, seldome or neuer quiet in times •• st, and in great garboile at this present. And againe if we cast •• r eyes somewhat further to the countries next adioininge, to the Empire in Germanie very potent in former times, & •• w much decayed; or to Spayne, first subiect to the Romans, Roderic. Toletan. Ioan. vassaeus.
•• er to the Goths, and then conquered by the Mores (solicited •• d brought in by the Spaniards them selues) then diuided into 〈◊〉 or. 7. seueral kingdomes and states, and now at length after •• ntinual ciuil warre for 6. or 7. hundreth yeares togeather, re
•• ced againe not many yeares agoe to one monarchy. Finally
for breuities sake (to range no further abroad then Italy) if weigh the innouations that haue succeeded therein, as wel this last age (by the bloody warrs betwixt the French and 〈◊〉
Spanish for the states of Milan and Naples, The often changes and innouations of diuers States in Italy. Blond. Sabel: lib. Singonius Guicciard. subiect sometim •• Kinges and Princes of their owne, and now made prouince •
Spayne) as also the mutation in former times not only in the states, but also in Rome it selfe, taken, and sacked, or at least be ••
ged 13. or 14. seueral times, and in al other partes of Italy miser •
bly distressed, spoiled, and ruined partly by the frequent irr ••
tions, and inundations of barbarous nations, (as Goths, Vand •• Alans, Huns, and Lumbards) and partly by inuasions of Germa ••
Emperours, and lastly by domestical and ciuil wars, proceedi •• otherwhiles of the ambitions of tirants in many particuler c •
ties, and sometimes of the furiours faction of the Guelfs and
••
belins (which for some yeares filled al states, citties, townes, 〈◊〉 and priuate howses with cruel slaughters and murthers of p •
rents, kinsfolkes, frinds, and of al sortes of people) someti •• againe by populer tumults and seditions, whereby there h •• bene noted in Genua ten notable changes of that state in 〈◊〉 space of 30. yeares, sometimes the common people preuailin ••
•
gainst the nobility; and some times the nobility against the p ••
ple, by which meane they are now brought to so low an eb •• that wheras they were able in times past to hold Compete •• with the state of Venice, yea and tooke the Duke of Venice pris •
ner in a battaile at sea) wherein they had 200. gailles of th •• owne (they haue not now past 25. and the same also waged 〈◊〉 paied by the Catholike King; if (I say) we weigh and conside • this, we may drawe from hence two notable documents.

Tvvo Documēts concerning the mutability and change of States.7. The first, the casualty and vanity of al humane pow •• honor, dignity, dominion, and glory, seeing they doe not o • perish sooner or later, but also are subiect, whiles they 〈◊〉 such mutation, and accompanied with infinit corrosiues and •
flictions, which consideration may iustly moue vs to eleuate 〈◊〉 cogitations from al earthly delights, to the contemplation 〈◊〉 desire of the heauenly,Seneca praefat. in li. 1. natural. quaest. that are ineffable, incompr • hensible, 〈◊〉 eternal. For as Seneca saith; nothing is more contemptible then 〈◊〉 he doe not raise and eleuate him selfe aboue himselfe.

8. The other document is, that considering the natural 〈◊〉
• obilitie, inconstancy and infirmity as wel of commonwelth as • f man him selfe, and of al earthly creatures; no humane wit, 〈◊〉 power, is more able to defend any kingdome, or common
• elth from declination, and decay, then to preserue a man from 〈◊〉 sicknes and mortalitie, or other earthly thinges from cor
•• ption.

div.head: • HE VVEAKNES OF MANS VVIT AND policy, is further proued by the imperfection of al political science, vvith a consideration of the imbecillity of lavv-makers exemplified in Solons lavves. By occasion vvhereof, a political question is debated concerning sedition. CHAP. 7.
div.p: IN the last chapter I shewed the insufficiencie, of mans wit for the gouernment of state, by the natural mutabilitie and instability of commonwelth: now I wil further proue the same by the defects and imperfection of humane policy.VVherein humane pollicy principally consisteth. And whereas the policy of man (for as much concerneth gouerment of commonwelth) consisteth either the institution, and the execution of good lawes, or in wise •• uncells, deliberatiōs, plots, & designments; I wil first speake lawes, and shew their insufficiencie for the establishment of •• te, not only in respect of the infirmitie of the law-maker, but so for the imperfection incident to lawe it selfe; I wil speake 〈◊〉 either a parte, and first of Law-makers.

2. For this purpose I wish thee (Good reader) to remember • hat I haue proued before in the beginning of this Treatise cō
•• rning the imbecilitie of mans wit, which I haue declared to •• e such, that no man can without the light of Gods grace, suf
•• ciently knowe and vnderstand what is conuenient and necessa
•• e for him selfe: which I made manifest, not only by reason,ca. 2. nu. 14. and •• e authoritie of holy Scriptures and graue authors, but also by • uident examples of the errors of great politikes and wisemen,ca. 3.4. & 5.
• ho haue bene either ruined, or at least greatly endangered by
the meanes whereby they thought to profit, and aduance the • selues.Cicero de Diuinatione. Whereupon I may wel inferre with the prouerbe, Qui s •• semitam non sapit, an alijs monstrabit viam? he which knowes 〈◊〉 the way him selfe, can he teach it to an other? that is to say, 〈◊〉 that knowes not what is good and fit for him selfe, can he 〈◊〉 able to iudge & determine what is conuenient for other men, ••
pecially for a whole commonweth?The diuersity of vvils & humors in euery cōmonvvelth. To this purpose it is to 〈◊〉 considered, (as I haue signified before) that there are such m ••
titudes of people, such difference of degrees, qualities, and conditions, and such peruersity of wills, humors, and affections 〈◊〉 euery commonwelth, that no humane wit is able to reduced the • to that perfect temperature, and harmony, which is requisite 〈◊〉 the conseruation of ciuil vnity and amity, to the end that al m •• continually concurre in the obedience of one lawe, in one kin • of gouernment, and liue therin contented each one in his ••
cation, in security, peace, and plenty, which euery law-maker • gouernour of commonwelth, ought to procure.

3. This may partly be iudged by the gouernment of a fami •• be it great or litle, which is many times turned vpside dow •• and disolued by the peruerse humor of some one, or two, n •• corrigible by any councel or chastisment of the head thero • What meruaile is it then, if in whole kingdomes and commo • welthes, amongst so many thousands of different persons, and 〈◊〉 different humors, there are many so exorbitant and turbule •• that no wit, nor power of man, can be able to tame or temp •• them? One man oftentymes the cause of the destruction of a whole Empire. Plutar. in Paulo Emilio. Roderic. Tole tan. li. 5. de reb. Hispan. c. 14. 15. 16. 17. 18. 19. Liuius Dec. • 3. lib. 2. Plutar. in Iul. Caesare. And doe we not see many times, that the couetousnes, 〈◊〉 the lust, or the treason, temeritie, or folly, or the ambition 〈◊〉 some one man, endangereth or ouerthroweth a whole empyr • The kingdome of Macedony was lost through the couetousnes 〈◊〉
Perseus king thereof; The treason of one count Iulian offended 〈◊〉 the lust of Roderike King of Spayne (who deflowred his daughte • was the cause that the Mores conquered Spayne, and posses •• 6. or 7. hundred yeares. The temerity of Terrentius Varro, whe •• he was Consul of Rome and gaue battaille to Hannibal, caused t •• great ouerthrowe which the Romans receaued at Cannae, to th • great danger of their commonwelth, which in the end was v •
terly ouerthrowne by the ambition of Iulius Caesar.

4. But what should I speake of a King of Macedony, or a Ki ••
of Spayne, or a Consul of Rome, or a Iulius Caesar, when the turbulent • umor of a base fellow, or pety companion, such a one I meane, 〈◊〉 a Blacksmith, or a Iacke Cade, or a Iacke Straw, The Garboyle and tumult in England raised by Iacke Cade and his fellowes. Stovv. Haul. Holinshed. hath bene able to • ut al England in a garboyle, to the great danger of the state; • eing then one fault or error of some one man, may ruyne, or •• danger a kingdome, how shal mans wit or policy be able, sus
• cienctly to preuent the inconuenience that must needes growe • y the infinit faultes and errors, which in tract of tyme are • ōmitted in euery commonwelth, by so many thousands as are • erein, through the folly or malice of men.

5. Furthermore, if we consider what the politike science whereby commonwelths are instituted, and gouerned) is able 〈◊〉 performe, and how far it may extend it selfe, we shal easely • e how litle perfection and establishment any state can receaue • y the law-maker, or gouernour therof, be he neuer so politike. • or whereas other sciences and artes were (as Aristotle teacheth) •• uented by some, augmented, and amplifyed by other,Arist. li. 2. Ele •
ch. c. vltimo. and • rought in time to perfection, it falleth out otherwayse in the • olitike science, which is so vncertaine and varyable, that al
• hough the rules & precepts therof,The Imperfection af al political science. were many hundreth yeares goe deliuered by most famous Philosophers, and explicated, and • mplified since by infinit authors ancient and moderne; yet both •• ason and experience sheweth, that it neuer arriueth, neither • n arriue to perfection. For nether one and the selfe same po
•• cy, is fit for al commonwelthes (as one art or science is fit and • onuenient for al kind of men) nether is commonwelth so du
•• ble in one manner and forme of gouernment, that the selfe •• me policy wil euer serue for the same; seing al cōmonwelthes • re subiect to mutation, and many tymes one is engendred by • he corruption of an other, euery one requiring different lawes, • nd a different policy.

6. And although the commonwelth doe remaine in one • orme of gouernment, as either in a Monarchy, Aristocracy, Foure kind of Lavves amongst the Romans. or a
• opoular State; yet such is the variety of times and instability of the • umors and affections of men, that new lawes and different po
• cies wil be necessarie thereto. And therfore where as the Ro
• ans had 4. kind of lawes, as Cicero testifyeth, one was De abro
• andis legibus, to abrogate and repel lawes,Cicero de le • . by the vertue and
authority wherof, many lawes made by very wise men, were ••
terwards by their posterity annulled and repealed, as vnprofitab •• and vnconuenient.

7. The same may be obserued in the very lawes of Go • which haue varied according to the different state of man a •• times, as it is euident by the lawe of Nature, the lawe of Moys ••
and now lastly the law of Grace. The reason whereof S. Augus •
giueth saying;Aug. li. 3. confess. c. 7. That it is not to be wondered at, that God ma •• different lawes, in different times; seeing that in one day, and 〈◊〉 one house, and in one man, one thinge is conuenient to o •• member, and another to another, and one thing to one man • and another, to another: and that the thinge which is exp •
dient now, wil an hower hence be vnlawful and inconuenie ••
Whereby it appeareth that time which breedeth certaintie 〈◊〉 iudgment and experience in men, for the perfection of oth •• sciences and artes, doth so change, & abolish lawes and po ••
cies, that it causeth in law-makers and gouernours, ignoran • errour, and confusion.

8. For this cause Plato affirmeth expresly, that no man be 〈◊〉 neuer so excellent of wit, or neuer so prudent and practis • in affaires,Gods inspiration necessary for the making of good Lavves. can be able without the inspiration and assistance God, to make sufficient lawes for the perfect establishment of commonwelth. And therfore in the institution of his ov •• written commonwelth, and of the lawes therof, he craueth help of almighty God, and otherwhere saith. That as brute beasts 〈◊〉 not be happily gouerned by beastes, without the help of man: so man can 〈◊〉 be wel & happily gouerned by man, without the help of God. And aga •• in an other place he teacheth;Plato. 4. de legibus. that as men cannot liue witho •• lawes, so neither could men haue had sufficient lawes, from P ••
metheus (that is to say from the prouidence of man) if Iupiter h •• selfe the creator of al,Idem, in Minoe. Idem in Protagora. had not sent Mercurie to men with lawe • be the interpreter of his diuine wil. Whereby he signifieth mi ••
cally after his manner, that without Gods special assistance, 〈◊〉 wit nor prouidence of man can suffice to institute, and co •
serue any state or commonwelth, either by the meanes of la •• or otherwise.

3. Reg. 3. 2. Paral. 2. 9. This also Salomon knew and acknowledged, who therfo •• craued wisdome of almighty God for the gouernment of 〈◊〉
people, adding; Quis enim potest iudicare populum istum, populum •• m hunc multum? For who can without thy helpe, Sap. 9. iudge and gouerne is thy people, so many in number. And againe; Giue me o Lord that wis
•• me which assisteth, thy seate, for I am a weake man; Et minor ad intel
•• tum indicij et legum; And not of capacity to vndersstand what is iudgmēt •• d lawe; Thus said this prudent King, considering, and humbly •• knowledging his owne infirmity, in respect whereof almighty •• d gaue him greater wisdome, wealth, honor, and glorie, then •• er had any earthly Prince.

10. But now for the further proofe of this matter, let vs exa
•• ne some of the lawes of 3 or 4. of the most famous law-makers at euer were; that by the discouery of their errors, the weak
•• s of mans wit in the institution and administration of cōmon
• elth, may the better appeare. And whereas some haue founded instituted commonwelthes indeed, and some only in writing,The lavves of foure famous Lavvmakers examined and reproued. serue for patternes for others; I wil speake here only of four of • eatest fame, of either sort two, as of Solon the Athenian, Licur
••
the Lacedemonian, Plato called the Deuine, and Aristotle maister Alexander the great.

11. When the commonwelth of the Athenians, hauing bene • uerned for many yeares togeather by the lawes of Dracon,
• s fallen to decay through the excessiue couetousnes & rigour • rich men, whome the poorer sort (being loaden with debts & • t able to pay them) were forced to serue as slaues by sentence the iudges, (wherupon there arose daily infinite tumults and •• ditions) it seemed good to them al, to recommend the reforma
•• n of their whole state to Solon, a man so highly esteemed for 〈◊〉 wisdome, that he was accounted one of the 7. wisemen of
•• eece, The Reformation of the commonvvelth of the Athenians by Solon. Plutar. in Solone. who perswading him selfe that it could not be conueni
• tly reformed, except the poore were releeued & eased of their •• bts, resolued to abolish & cancel al contracts and obligations 〈◊〉 debts past, imparting his minde therin first to some of his in
•• e freends, who seing his resolution, borrowed great store of • oney, & emploid it in land, whereupon it followed that when
•• on published his new lawe (which he called Seysacthia that is 〈◊〉 say A discharge of debts) they remained exceedingly enriched, •• eir creditors defrauded, and he much suspected of deceit, as to •• ue had secret intelligence with his frends, and part of their •• ine.

Tvvo soule errors of Solon about the reformation of the Athenian commonvvelth.12. And although it seemeth that therin he had wronge 〈◊〉 he lost by his one law, as some write 15. talents which 〈◊〉 owing him) yet he can not be excused in two thinges, the one that he caused not his frends to restore the money which th • had guilfully borrowed; and the other, that without exami ••
tion of the particuler causes and reasons of euery mans debt, 〈◊〉 ordained a general abolition of al debts good and bad; where aswel those which were able to pay, as the vnable were disch ••
ged, and al creditours without difference defrauded,Cioe. offi • : li. 2. contrarie al equitie and iustice, which (as Cicero saith speaking of the li •• case) requireth aboue al thinges,Great iniustice committed by Solon. Ibid. that euerie man haue his ow • and that equal regard be had to the right, aswel of the rich, as 〈◊〉 the poore (which saith he) is no way obserued; Cum locupl •• suum perdunt, & debitores lucrentur alienum; When riche 〈◊〉 loose their owne, and debitors gaine that which belongeth other men. Besides that, in this case the necessitie was not s •• to breake iustice so notoriously; for that the inconuenien •• might haue bene remedied otherwise, without iniurie to a •• as partly by the meanes,Hovv Solon might haue reformed the commonvvelth vvithout the breach of Iustice. which he him selfe also practised, 〈◊〉 wit, by raysing the money, and partly by borrowing some gr •• sommes with the which he might haue made at least some co •• position with the creditours, in behalfe of the debitors & h •• repaied the money after in time by penalties, confiscations, 〈◊〉 some moderate taxes, whereby the poore might haue bene 〈◊〉 the present releeued, and no man wronged.

Cicero Ibid.13. Therfore Cicero greatly commendeth, Aratus, who w •• the cittie called Sicione had bene 50. yeares opprest by tyra •• and he him selfe banished with 600. others of the richest m •• therin, first found meanes to kil the tyrant, and after hau •• called home al those that were banished, and finding difficu •• in restoring them to their goods and liuings (which were the possessiō of other men & had bene in 50. yeares space alie ••
ted by many contracts, and bargaines of sales, dowries, leases 〈◊〉 such like) thought it not conuenient, either to take the said •
uings from those that possessed them, or yet to leaue the ot •• vnsatisfied.The vvisdome of Aratus in •• forming the ••• y of Sc • one. And therfore he borrowed a great some of mon • of Ptolomeus King of Alexandria, & examining euery mans cau •• & making an estimate of the landes, so delt betwixt the par •••
that for readie money, some of them were content to leaue their •• ssession, & others to sel their right, and surcease their claime, • hereby peace and concord was made, al men satisfied; Et sic par (saith Cicero) cum Ciuibus agere, & non alijs sua eripere, Ibidem. alijs dare •• na; So it is fit to deale with subiects, and not to take from some their •• e, and to giue it to others to whome it doth not belong; as Solon did, •• o therfore was to be blamed, not only for errour, but also •• r iniustice.

14. I omit other errours of Solon, which might be obserued the forme of his commonwelth,An absurd lavv of Solon forbidding neutrality in a publike sedition. Plutar in Solone. to come to the examina
••• n of one of his lawes, by the which he ordained, That who
••• uer in any publike sedition, should be neutral and take neither part, • uld remayne euer after infamous; his reason was, for that he •• ought it not conuenient, that any man should so much loue 〈◊〉 owne ease, as not to participate of the trouble of the com
• onwelth whereof he was a member. Which reason, togeather •• th the lawe, Plutark worthelie and wiselie reiecteth,Idem, in his booke of instructions for such as deale in matters of state. for that would be an assured meanes to put (as it were) fyer to gun
•• wder, and to set al the commonwelth on a flame, without •• pe of any internal remedie; For (saith he) euen as in sick body, • he hope of helpe with in it selfe, is to be expected from the partes that sound (and therfore when the body is wholy corrupted, there is no helpe • emedy but from abroad) euen so in politike body sicke with sedetion, Solons lavv reiected by Plutarke.
• he internal remedie is to come from the whole and sound partes therof;
• at is to say; from such as are neutralls, who may labour with •• e one part and with the other to compound the quarrel; for • therwise where al is in tumult no remedie can be expected; ex
•• t it come from abroad.Ibidem. A principal point of political science either to preuent seditions, or quickly to appease them. And therfore Plutarke houldeth it for •• e highest and principal point of politike science in any gouer
• ur, know how either to preuent seditions, that they neuer • owe, or else quickly to appease them, when they are growne, 〈◊〉 they neuer so litle. For euen as the least sparke that is, may fal to such matter, that it may set a whole house on fyer; so the •• st ciuil sedition may fal amongst such persons, & in such time, •• t it may put a whole commonwelth in combustion, and vt
•• lie ruine it; and for this cause, wise gouernours haue an eye •• t only to dissentions concerning the commonwelth and pu
•• ke matters; but also of priuate quarrels, though it be amongst
meane men, for that many times they redound to the publike d •
triment: wherof of Plutark recounteth a notable example.

15. Two young men of Siracusa were so great freends, th •• the one of them being to goe abroad vpon an occasiō, recome •
ded vnto the other the care of his concubyn; the other in hi • absence, being ouercome with loue and lust, abused her; 〈◊〉 reuenge wherof, Plut. Ibidem. A Storie of the dissention of tvvo yong men of Sy • ac • sa. his freend at his retourne corrupted the othe • wife, by which meanes there grew a great quarrel betwixt them and the matter comming to the notice of the Senat, wise Sen •••
gaue councel to banish them both, least their priuate quarr •• might breed some publike sedition; But his aduise was negl •
cted, wherupon it followed that the freends of either takin • their partes, made within a while such a tumult and ciuil warr • in the cittie, that the whole state was ouerthrowne therby.

16. But as al priuate quarrells may proue dangerous to th • commonwelth, so most of al when they growe betwixt gre •• personages. Phil. de Com. Cron. du roy Louis ca. 138. The danger that grovveth to a prince by maintening diuision amongst his subiectes. In which respect, Philip de Comines blameth grea •• such princes, as doe not seeke to compose dissentions and qua •
rells amongst some of their greater subiects, but rather nouri •• them by fauoring one partie more then the other, wherein th •• doe no other (saith he) but helpe to set their owne howse ••
fier.

17. Wherof he alleageth 2. notable examples: the one of t •• Queene of England (wife to Kinge Henrie the 6.) who taki •• part with the Duke of Sommerset against the Earle of VVarwi ••
was a special cause of that warre,VVarre in England betvvixt the K. and Earle of VVarvvicke. Ibidem. which the Earle made ma •• yeares togeather, against the King and house of Lancaster to the •• vtter ouerthrowe, and therfore (saith he) the Queene shou •• haue done much mo • e wisely, if she had shewed herselfe 〈◊〉 the first indifferent betwixt the two parties, and helped to •
gree them.

18. The other example which he alleadgeth, is, of Charles t •• 7. King of France: who when he was Dolphin tooke parte with t •• Duke of Orleance, Henry the fifth of England crovvned in France. against the Duke of Burgundy in a priuat quar •• of theirs. In reueng wherof the Duke of Burgundy, called Hen •••
the 5. King of England into France, and helped to crown him and his sonne after him kings in Paris.

19. And whereas Philip de Comines seemeth to take it for 〈◊〉
inconuenience, that a young Prince should sometimes for his • port,Philip de Comines reproued for allovving in a young Prince to nourrish quarrels amongst the Ladies in his court. Plin. de viris illuster. Liu. dec. 1. lib. 6. The troubles that often arise by the dissension of vvomen. and pleasure nourish some iarres & quarreles amongst the • adies and Gentlewomen of his court, I can not but dissent from • im therin: for that womens iarres may make mens warres. And • xperience hath taught, that mutations haue sometimes hapned • n States by womens quarrels. As in Rome, where Fabius Ambustus
• auing maried his two daughters, the elder to a noble man cal
•• d Sulpitius (who was after made Consul) and the younger to a •• ebiean called Licinius Stolo (who by the lawes was not capable • f that dignitie) it chansed that a disgust fel betwixt the two •• sters, for that the younger visiting the elder (who was then • ife to the Consul) and houlding her selfe to be contemned of • er, in respect of her meaner estate, lamented so pittifully to her •• ther, that to appease her, he practised with the people to • ake his sonne in-law Licinius Stolo Consul, in derogation of the • ncient law and custome, which excluded the plebeians from the • onsulshippe. And although the cheife Senators opposed them •• erto, with might and maine, as to a great nouelty, and a matter • ery preiudicial to the dignitie of the Senate, yet he preuailed, & • ot only procured a decree, that from thence forward the ple
• eians might be Consuls, but also obtained the election of Licinius •• olo his sonne in-law. And this was done, to satisfy the disdaine • f a woman against her owne sister.

20. But more dangerous & lamentable was the quarrel of • wo sisters in-law in England, in the time of Edward the 6.The dissension betvvene the Duches of Somerset and Q. Kath. Parre in England. where
• f the one was Queene Catherine Parre, lately before wife to King
• enry the 8. and then married to the Lord Thomas Seymer Admiral
• f England, and the other was the Duches of Somerset, wife to the • ord Protector of England, brother to the Admiral. These two La
• ies failling at variance for the precedence,Sander. de schismate Anglic. lib. 2. which either of them • hallenged, the one as Queene Douager, and the other as wife to • he Protector (who then gouerned the King, and al the Realme) •• rewe their husbands into the quarrel, and so incensed the one • f them against the other, that the Protector procured the death • f the Admiral his brother; whereupon also followed his owne • estruction shortly after: for being depriued of the assistance and • upport of his brother, he was easely ouerthrowne by the Duke • f Northumbarland, who caused him to be conuicted of fellony
and beheaded. Loe then what inconuenience followed of t •• falling out of two women: therfore Aristotle wisely aduise •• Princes to haue care,Aristot. Poli. li 5. ca. 2. that their wiues doe no disgraces, nor gi •• iust cause of disgust to the wiues of their subiects, for that (sai •• he (commonwelthes haue bene ouerthrowne by such meane •

21. But what maruaile is it if the quarrels of women may 〈◊〉 dangerous to the commonwelth, seeing a famous and pernitio • faction in Italy, A quarrel begun betvvixt tvvo boyes in Italy, caused much bloodshed. Tarcagnota hist. mundi par. 2. l. 15. began by the occasion of a quarrel betwixt t •• boyes, whereof the one gaue the other a box on the eare: in r •
uenge whereof, the father of the boy that was stroken, cut of th • hand of the other that gaue the blowe, whose father making th • quarrel his owne, sought the reuenge of the iniurie done to 〈◊〉 sonne, & began the faction of the Neri, and the Bianchi, that is 〈◊〉 say, black & white, which presently spred it selfe throwout Italy & was the occasion of spilling much Christian blood. Whereb • we may see how necessarie it is for gouernours to haue an eye 〈◊〉 quarrels, though amongst meane persons: and how dangerous is for a Prince to make diuision in his state betwixt great pers •
nages,The danger of Machiauels doctrin concerning diuision. Arist. l. 5. Pol. c. 11. to ballance & counterpeise one of them with an oth •• to the end they shal not conspire against him, as Machiauel cou •
selleth absurdly, following the old tyrannical precept. Si vis 〈◊〉 nare, diuide. If thou wilt raigne, make diuision. As though it should 〈◊〉 alwaies in the Princes power, to moderate the same at his pl ••
sure, whereof no mortal creature can assure him selfe, (be he n •
uer so wise or potent) And therfore we may say of such dāgero •• courses,Ecclesiast. c. 3. as saith the booke of Ecclesiasticus. Qui amat periculum, p ••• bit in illo. He which loues danger, shal perish in it.

22. Neuerthelesse to retourne now to Solons law (which co •
demneth neutrality in publike seditions or factions) althoug • in some cases the said law would be pernitious to commōwelt • yet in some other I hold it so necessary,In vvhat cases Neutralitie is to be alovved, or disalovved. as that no man cou •• doe his duty either to God, or his country, except he should p •• the same in practise. As for example, if the quarrel were for m ••
ter of religion, or touching either the seruice of God, or the p •
blike good of the commonwelth, or for the iust defence of th • lawful prince, and gouernour therof; in which cases al neutrality were vnlawful. For when there is question of Gods seruice, to be neutral,Neutrality vnlauful in diuisions concerning Gods seruice. Luc. 11. were nothing else but to betray Gods cause, and 〈◊〉
declare a mans selfe to be his enemie, according to our Sauiours • ying. Qui non est mecum, contra me est, & qui non colligit mecum, spergit; He which is not with me, is against me, he vvhich gathereth • t vvith me, scattereth. And therfore the neutrals in that case, are • ose whome the Holy Ghost calleth Tepidi, men that are luke
•• rme, of whome the Scripture saith in the person of God; vti
• m esses aut calidus, aut frigidus, sed quia tepidus es,
Apocalip. 3. euomam te ex ore • o: I would thou vvert either hot, or cold, but because thou art but luke
•• rme, I wil therfore spit thee out of my mouth.

23. Againe in the other case,Neutralitie condemned in matters concerning the iust defence of the Prince or commonvvelth. where the controuersie concer •
th the good of the commonwelth, or the iust defence of the • ad therof, neutralitie were in effect treason, and should merit • t only the note of infamie (as Solons law ordained) but also • y rigorous punishment whatsoeuer. And therfore in al such • ses, al men are bound in conscience and duty without delay, 〈◊〉 declare at least their good wil & affections to the maintenāce 〈◊〉 the iust cause, and when perswasions wil not suffice, then to •• ploie al their force, yea & their liues for the suppression of the • ditions, rather then to suffer them to preuaile.

24. But in other cases (as when some particuler mens priuate • ssention doth growe to a publike sedition, or when the con
•• tion is not betwixt the head and some of the members, but • etwixt the members them selues) to adhere to either partie (as
•• lons law commanded) were no other then in steede of water,Neutrality in priuate quarrels condemned.
• herewith to quench fier to cast in oyle to nourish & augmēt 〈◊〉 to the great danger and detriment of the whole state. There
• re in such a case, the neutral & indifferent man may best helpe 〈◊〉 remedie the disease of the commonwelth, putting on (as Plu
•• ke saith) the buskin of Theramenes, which serued for both feete, Plut. in his instruct. for such as deale in matters of state.
• at is to say, dealing indifferently with both parties to draw •• em to composition, not for his owne ease, or to auoid the par
• cipation of the publike or common calamitie (as Solon in his •• w supposed of al neutrals) but to extinguish the fier kindled 〈◊〉 the commonwelth, or at least not to minister further matter •• erto by any act of his. This then we see how Solon erred in his •• wes, & ordinances,Arist. polit. li. 2. ca. 10. though Aristotle seemeth to preferre him • efore al other law-makers, censuring and controwling al the est, and excusing him in that, wherein others reprehended him,
and concluding him to be an excellent law-maker, as also Pl •••
doth,Plato de legib. who for patternes and examples for al such as shal instit ••• commonwelths and lawes, proposeth Minos, Solon, and Licurgu •• ,
〈◊〉 which last, I wil therfore speak next.

div.head:
THE IMBECILLITY OF LAVV-MAKERS I • also exemplified in certaine wicked and absurd lawes of Licu •
gus, Plato, and Aristotle, with certaine obseruations no le ••
pious then political. CHAP. 8.
div.p:
Plat. in Licurgo. LICVRGVS was no lesse famous for his ro •• birth, then for his great wisdome, and me •• vertue, who being brother to Polidectes King 〈◊〉
Lacedemony, succeeded him in the kingdome 〈◊〉 the earnest request of the people (in respe •• that his brother left no issue, but only his v ••• great with child) and being earnestly solicited by her to ma •• with her, with promise to destroy the child in her wombe ( 〈◊〉 the end that his kingdome might be the more assured) he 〈◊〉 not only refuse it, but also when the child was borne, & prou •• a Sonne, he proclaimed him King, taking only to him selfe t •• tutele of him, and the gouernment of the realme during his m •
noritie, with intention in the meane time to reforme it, b ••• growne to great corruption,Of the lavves of the Lacedimonians reformed by Licurgus. and al most vtterly decaied; & the ••
fore he abolished most of the old lawes, and ordained new, the vse whereof the Lacedemonians flowrished many yeares abo •• al the rest of the Grecians, in so much that they had the domi ••
on of al Greece for some time.

2. Neuertheles if we examine his commonwelth, and 〈◊〉 lawes thereof, we shal find, that he failed both in true p ••
dence,Hovv Licurgus erred in framing his common vvelth rather for vvarres then for peace. and in moral vertue. For whereas a good law-mak • ought to frame his commonwelth no lesse to Religion, Iustic •• and Temperance, then to fortitude, that it may stand & flowris • as wel in time of peace, as in time of warre, his lawes tend • principaly to make the people valiant, and warlike, whereup ••
it followed, that the Lacedemonians flowrished so long as they •• d warres, and when they came to enioie peace, they felle to •• cay with in a while (as Aristotle noteth) wherby the error of
•• urgus euidently appeareth.Arist. poli. li. 2. ca. 7. For as peace is not ordained for • arre, but warre for peace, as motion and labour is ordained •• r rest (in which respect Cicero sayeth: VVarre is so to be vndertaken, Cicero. offic. lib. 1. that peace may be attained therby) so in like manner, a common
• elth is rather to be framed and ordained for peace, then for • arre; And yet so for both, that it may stand by both. In which •• spect the commonwelth of the Athenians as Plutarke noteth,Plutark in Phocione & pelopida.
•• ose Pallas for their patronesse, who was called both Polemica &
•• litica, that is to say, VVarlike, and Ciuil: as also the Thebans had for • eirs, Harmony, which was held to be the daughter of Mars and
•• us, wherby they signified, that the harmony of cōmon-welth •• nsisteth in the consonance, and coniunction of military and •• il discipline;Iustinia. Institut. in proemio. which also Iustinian signified in the institutes of •• e ciuil lawe, saying: Imperatoriam maiestatem, &c. It is conuenient • t the Imperial maiesty, be not only decked, and adorned with armes, but 〈◊〉 defended with lawes.

• . But in the commonwelth of the Lacedemonians this was no •• y performed; For, the lawes of Licurgus, tending only to make •• em stronge, laborious, and valiant, could not make them reli
• ous, iust, and truly temperate, which for ciuil discipline and • aceable gouerment is most requisite. For, as for lawes tending 〈◊〉 religion, we find none made by Licurgus, A ridiculous lavv of Licurgus Plutar. in Licurgo. not any religious act • his, but only one more rediculous, then religious, as that he • dicated an Image to laughter, which he made a God, or at least • ould haue to be worshiped for a God, to make the people • erry at their publike feastes, and meetinges. And as for lawes • rtaining to iustice, he made few, and one amongst the rest; • hich opened a great gap to iniustice, and to al consonage & de
•• it; for he ordained, that it should be lawful for any man, to •• ale any kind of meate (so that he were not taken or disco
•• red in the doing of it) and that boies and children should •• ue so litle allowed them to eate,Idem. Ibid. that they should be forced to •• ole, and steale for their better prouision, to make them ther
•• the more industrious, nimble, and quick of spirit, and others • ore wary & watchful to keepe wel that which they had, in so
much that he which could steale most cunningly was most co •
mended.

4. But who seeth not that this was the next way to fil t •• commonwelth with theeues;Cunning theft and deceit allovved of in the lavves of Licurgus. For is it likely that those who fro • their infancy are brought vp in stealing, & pilfering trifles, wil ••
terwardes (when they haue got the habit & hability therof) f •• beare to steale thinges of greater importance? Or can thee 〈◊〉 practise their occupation with more safety any way to beco •• in the end most expert, and thereby pernitious to the commo •
welth, then with the warrant, and vnder the protection of th • law? seeing the penaltie which was ordained for them that we •• taken with the maner, was not inflicted for the iniustice of th • fact, but for their lack of skil and dexterity in the performanc • which must needes make euery one labour to excelle in th • act of the euery: Finally when the law not only permitteth, 〈◊〉 also induceth men to deceaue, some times, and in some thing •• doth it not also dispose, and as it were, direct them to decea •• as ofte, and howsoeuer they may? Therfore good and wise la • makers, seeke to preuent euils, and to cut of the occasions 〈◊〉 vice, and not to minister matter or occasion thereto, which 〈◊〉 our corrupt natures, needeth a bridle to restraine it, and nor 〈◊〉 spurre ro prick it forward.

5. And this may also be said in respect of an other lawe of
••
curgus inducing to intemperancy, and al kind of incontinen •• For although he ordained some thinges notably for the educ •
tion of youth;Idem. Ibid. tending as it seemed, to the repression of con ••
piscence, and dissolute life, (as a very spare and homelie diet hard bedding of reedes (or as some write) no beds at al,Iustin. li. 3. con ••
nual labour and exercise, one only garment, for the whole yea and such like) yet it appeareth that his meaning was no ot •• therin, but only to make them able to endure the labour, a ••
toile of warre; For he ordained other lawes so much in fauo •• and furtherance of lust, & of al carnallity, yea in the worst kin • that it may iustly be said,Plut. Ibid. he made his whole commonwe ••• worse then a burdel; For he instituted certaine wrestlinges an • dances,Absurd lavvs of Licurgus tending to Lasciuiousnes. and other exercises of boyes and wenches naked, to b • done in publike at diuers times in the yeare, in the presen • both of young & old men, which what effect it might worke 〈◊〉
the mindes and manners of their citizens, any man may easely • dge; especially seeing both their lawes & customes, permitted • at men should be enamored of boyes, which was held for lau
• ble and necessary for their good education, it being presumed •• t their louers would carefully instruct them in vertue.

6. Furthermore adultry which was punished with death,Leuit 20. l •• Iulia. not •• ly by the law of Moyses, but also by the law of the Romans and • her nations, as a thinge pernitious to commonwelth, was not •• ly permited, but also approued by Licurgus his law; ordaining,Adulterie permitted by Licurgus amongst the Lacedimonians.
•• t if an old man married a young wife, she might with her hu
•• nds licence, make choice of any young man that she liked to •• ue a child by him, which her hushand brought vp as his owne. •• d if a valiant, or vertuous man (as good soldiers were termed • ere) liked wel of an other mans wife, he might demand leaue her husband to haue issue by her, which was not denied, but • ought cōueniēt for their commonwelth to maintaine there in good race, and breed of valiant men,Plut. in Licurg. as Plutark signifieth in • fence of this law of Licurgus.

7. This then being soe; Arist. li. 2. pol. ca. 7. The ouerthrovv of the Lacedimonyans in the playne of Leuctra, by Gods iust iudgement for their sinnes of the flesh. Plut. narratione amator. Diodorus Siculus. li. 15. ca. 14. ca. 20. nu. 3. what maruaile it is that al sinne of •• e flesh and beastlines raigned more in Lacedemony, then any •• ere els in Greece, as Aristotle witnesseth? Nay what wonder is it •• t almighty God of his iust iudgment plagued them for it in 〈◊〉 end? with a memorable ouerthrow in the plaine of Leuctra,
• ere they lost the dominion of Greece, by the occasion, and for •• nishment of a horrible rape, committed by two of their citti
•• s, as I wil declare more at large when I come to treate of •• ds iustice.

•• n, I wil not stand vpon other thinges reproued by Aristotle

But what God was 〈◊〉 marry he which shakes the highest temples of the heauenes with thunder, 〈◊〉 therfore might not I that am but a poore wretch doe the like? yes truly I 〈◊〉 and that with al my harte.

ctures of the gods,Aristotles absurditie manifest. must needes worke in the mindes of such 〈◊〉 should behold them, and be withal religiously affected toward • them. Hereby two things appeare euidētly; the one, the weak •• of mans wit when it is not supported and directed by the gr ••• of God;The vveaknes of mans vvit and the imperfection of lavves inferred vpon the premises. and the insufficiencie, and imperfection of hum •• lawes, through the weaknes of the law-makes, who intendi •• many times to make good and wholesome lawes for the ben
•• of the commonwelth, doe ordaine thinges very inconuenie •• and preiudicial therto; which Cicero obserued in some of t •• wisest men of his time; I can tel you (saith he) of Marcus Cotta wi •• lawe concerning priuate iudgments, Cicero de rep. in fragmentis was abrogated by his owne brother 〈◊〉 same yeare that it vvas made, and the lavves of Licinia, and Mutiae made

•• eiae, and Apuliae to be nothinge worth. Thus far Cicero. The like • hereof might be exemplified in euery commonwelth, but this •• al suffice at this time concerning law-makers. And now let vs • onsider law in it selfe, what it is, to what end it is ordained, and • hat it can performe in commonwelth, for the perfection and •• tablishment therof.

div.head: • HE IMPERFECTION OF HVMANE LAvves is further shevved by the defects incident to lavv: And first vvhat lavv is, to vvhat end it is ordained, and vvhat it can performe in commonvvelth. Also an exact comparison of the lavv of the flesh) vvhich is contrary to commonvvelth) vvith political lavv, vvherby it appeareth that political lavv can not ouercome the carnal lavv. CHAP. 9.
div.p:
PLATO speaking generally of al law,Plato in Mino. de rep. & de leg. as wel written as vnwritten, defineth it to be; A reasonable rule leading and directing men to their due end, for a publike good, ordaining penalties for them that transgressé, and revvards for them that obay. And Cicero more breefly thus;Cicero. li. 1. de. legib. Idem. Ibid. Lavv is (saith hee) the highest or chiefe •• son grafted in nature, cōmanding those thinges vvhich are to be done, and •• bidding the contrary. And againe. Lavv is the force of nature, the vn
•• rstanding and reason of a wiseman, the rule of right and wronge. The definition of lavv. And •• eaking more particulerly of written law, he saith it is; The rea
•• and vnderstanding of a wise man, who ordaineth in vvriting vvhat he •• inketh good, by vvay either of cōmandement, or of prohibition. Lastly •• e Ciuilians most breifly, & properly define it thus.Accurs. in instit. ff. de legibus. & Senatus constit. 3. Lex est sanctio •• cta, iubens honesta, prohibens contraria. Law is a holy decree, (that to say, a decree which ought not to be broken) commanding • ood and holy thinges, and forbidding the contrary.

Plato. de leg.2. This law Plato calleth, the soule that giueth forme 〈◊〉 life to the cōmonwelth, & the ancor that staieth & assureth it 〈◊〉
Cicero saith, Cicero l. 3. de leg. Lavv is the soule and life of the commonvvelth. that neither any house, nor citty, nor nation, nor y •• humane kind could stand with out it.

3 Neuertheles how excellent or necessary soeuer it is fo • commonwelth, yet it is to be vnderstood, that al lawes wha • soeuer (that are meerly humane) are defectiue and insufficient for the perfect gouerment of a state.Al lavves defectiue. Lavves vvriten or vnvvriten. Idem. Ibid. The magistrate a speaking lavv, and the lavv, a dūme magistrate For whereas humane lawe • consist ether in written statutes & decrees, or in the commandement and ordinances of a wise magistrate (which magistrate Cicero therfore calleth A speaking law, as he also calleth the law, A dumme magistrate) it is euident that nether of both a part, no • yet both concurring, can suffice.

4. As for the first, wheras written lawes are vniuersal, an • concerne the actions of men,The imperfection if vvritten lavves. which are infinit and particular, it is not possible that any law-maker should extēd his lawes so far, that they may sufficiently prouide for al cases that may occurre but that he must leaue place for the determination and iudgement of men according to equity, as not only Aristotle, but al •• the Ciuilians themselues doe teach,Arist. ethic. li. 5. c. 10. Iulian. li. 19. ad edictum. ff. de legib. & senatus constit. 3. & Iulian. li. 89. dige • t. and the experience is dail •• seene therof in the necessity of interpretation and mitigation o • lawes, in dispensations, and in appellations from law to conscience, wherby the imperfection of al written lawes sufficient •• appeareth. And as for the ordinances of wise magistrats, it is manifest by that which I haue said before concerning the errors o • wise gouernours & law-makers, that the weaknes and blindne •• of mans wit,The imperfection of vnvvritten lavves. Better to be gouerned by good lavves, then by the vvil of the best man, and vvhy. Arist. polit. li. 3. c. • 2. VVhere good lavves gouerne God doth gouerns. and the corruption of his nature is such, that he ca • nether see so cleerely in al cases, nor yet be so voide of affectio • and passion, that he shalbe able alwaies to determine, decree • and iudge according to equity. In which respect Aristotle disp ••
ting whether it were better that a commonwelth should be gouerned by good lawes, or by the wil of the best man, preferret • the gouernment of lawes before the other, saying, that The lavv i • as it vvere a pure and cleare vnderstanding: vvhereas the vnderstanding o • the best man is ioyned vvith sensual appetite, vvherby it may be corrupted And that therfore where the law gouerneth, there God gouerneth with the law, but where man gouerneth, be he neuer s • wise and vertuous, there a cruel beast (to wit concupisence an •
passion) entreth in to the gouerment with him, and many times • bscureth his vnderstanding, and peruerteth his wil. As the magistrates should gouerne the people so should lavv gouerne the magistrate. Iulian li 15. digest. ff. de legib & Senatus. constit. 3. Cicero de leg li. 3. For which • ause the magistrates ought in al cases, wherein the meaning of • he law is cleare, to iudge and determine, according to the pre
• cript therof (as the Ciuil law it selfe ordaineth) and Cicero saith, •• at as the magistrate gouerneth the people, so should the lavv gouerne the • agistrat. Wherupon I infer, that seing no law-maker can so su
•• iciently prouide for the gouernment of commonwelth by the •• tter of the law, but that he must leaue infinit cases, yea and the •• terpretation of the lawes themselues to the determination & •• dgment of men (who are also on their parte defectiue,No sufficient meanes to make a perfect commonvvelth by human lavves or magistrates. to wit •• biect to passion and error) it followeth that nether the law • ithout the magistrate, not the magistrate without the law, nor •• t both cōcurring, can suffice for the perfect gouernmēt of cō
• onwelth, but should be for to supply the defects of the other. • nd therfore I conclude, that there is no sufficient meanes & • ssured, to establish any state by humane lawes.

5. This wil be more euident if we cōsider what are the special • nds wherto lawes are ordained, & what they can performe. • wo thinges are principally intended by them:Tvvo princial ends vvhereunto humayne lavves do tend. the one the ad
• inistration of iustice by the decision of causes, controuersies, • nd sutes, betwixt partie, and party; The other is, the reforma
•• on of manners, and repression of vice, for that it is pernicious 〈◊〉 commonwelth. Of the first, I haue already spoken sufficient
•• , hauing declared as wel the weaknes of the law-maker, and • agistrate, as the imperfection of the law in the determination • f causes, and therfore I wil enlarge my selfe here a litle further • oncerning the later, which is suppression of vice and reforma
•• on of manners, and wil declare that humane lawes can not su
•• ciently performe, either the one, or the other.

6. For if lawes were able to reforme mens manners, ff. de legib. & Senatus consult. tit. 3. Isidor. li. 5. Etimolog. The force of humane lavves consisteth in precepts, prohibition, permission, revvard and punishment. or to •• presse vice, they must doe it either by precept, or by prohibition, or •• y permissiō, or by rewardinge, or by punishinge: for in these fiue thin
• es consist al the force of humane lawes, as the Lawiers them • elues do testifie. As for the two first, to wit, precept & prohibition,
•• ey are altogeather vnable and insufficient to bring the cor
•• pt nature of man to any perfection of vertue. For what other • elp haue we therby but only the knowledge of our duty; which
knowledge alone as Aristotle saith,Arist. lib. 2. Ethic. cap 4. helpeth little or nothing to vert •• wherof the praise and commendation consisteth in action, and operation. F •• it nothing auaileth though we know neuer so much, if we, d •• not put our knowledg in practise. And as it little profiteth a si •• man to knowe what meate is good for him, when he hath suc • a loathing to it that he can not eate it; euen so the corrupt nature of man hath little helpe or remedy by the knowledge of hi • duty; when vertue is so loathsome vnto him, that he can not brooke it. Seneca ep. 95. Preceptes alone litle auail to the obtaining of vertue. For as Seneca saith; Nihil proderit dare praecepta, nisi pri •• amoueris obstantia praeceptis. It is to little purpose to giue precep •• except thou first remoue the obstacles therof. Therfore the poe • saith truely.

q.l: — si possem, sanior essem;
Sed trahit inuitum, noua vis, aliudque cupido,
Mens aliud suadet, Video meliora proboque,
Deteriora seauor.

div.p:
That is to say, I would be better if I could, but a new and strange fo •• dravveth me against my vvil, and sensuality perswades me one thing • and reason an other; I see and approue the better, but I follow the vvos ••
Also the Apostle speaking in the person of our corrupt natu •• testifieth the same saying. Rom. 7. Scio quia non habitat in me &c. I know t • there dwels no goodnes in me, that is to say, in my flesh, for I haue a g •• wil or desire, but I can not performe it, for I doe not the good which I des •• to doe, but I doe the euil vvhich I would not doe. Thus far the Apostle wherupō it followeth that the precept & prohibitiō of the la • (wherby we haue only the knowledge of good and euil) littl • auaileth vs for the attaining of vertue, except the infirmitie & corruption of nature be cured by some other meanes. For A ••
mus (saith Seneca) vt ad praecepta posit ire, Sene. ep. 95. soluendus est: that is to s ••
The soule must be loosed from the bonds that tie & entangle it, or other v ••• it can not followe the good precepts that are giuen. But what if the pr •
hibition of euil doth hurt also, if it be not otherwaies helped?

Rom 7. Prohibition of it selfe rather hurteth then other vvayes.7. This the Apostle proueth clearly, to shew therby the inf ••
mitie of the Mosaycal law, considered in it-selfe without Go • grace; Peccatum (saith he) non cognoui, &c. I knew not sinne but 〈◊〉 th • law, for I knew not concupiscence, but because the law said, th •• sh • lt not couet. And sinne by the occasion of the cōmandment hath wroug • al concupiscence in me: thus far the Apostle. And how true this 〈◊〉
cōmon experience may teach vs; seing nothing is more proper • nd peculier to the malice of mans nature, then the desire to doe • hat which is forbidden, and commonly for no other reason, but • ecause it is forbidden, which the poët signifieth elegantly, • ying.

q.l: Cui peccare licet, peccat minus;Ouidius. 3. de arte amandi. ipsa potestas
Semina nequitiae languidiora facit. &c.
Nitimur in vetitum semper, cupimusque negata:
Sic interdictis imminet aeger aquis.

div.p:
• e which hath leaue to sinne, sins lesse, for the liberty to sinne weakeneth •• e very roots and seedes of sinne: Mans corrupt nature thirsteth after thinges forbidden. Horatatius. 1. Carminum. od 3.
we alwayes striue to doe that which is •• rbidden vs, like to the sick man, who thirsts most after forbidden wa
••• ; And an other Poët saith to the same purpose. Gens humaruit per vetitum nefas. Mankind runneth head longe to sinne when it is ••• bidden him; For euen as a torrent or land-floud running a vio
•• nt and precipitous course, and meeting with any stop by the • ay becomes the more furious, and with redoubled force makes selfe way, and beareth downe al before it: Euen so mans cor
•• pt nature, being carried headlong with vnbridled desiers, & ••• ding it selfe repressed or hindered with any law or comand
• ent, breaketh downe the bankes and bounds of duty with 〈◊〉 doubled fury, in such sorte, that it committeth double offence: 〈◊〉 wit, it doth not only do the euil that it desireth, but also bre
•• eth the law, as the Apostle insinuateth saying; Lex iram operatur.
Rom. 4.
• c. The law worketh or causeth vvrath, for vvhere there is no lavv, there is 〈◊〉 breach of lavv. Whereupon Saint Augustine saith,In decerptis ex August. The letter of the 〈◊〉 killeth, for it makes a man rather knovv euil, then eschew it, and by ••• t meanes rather encreaseth then diminisheth sinne, for that mans concupi
•• nce, or vnlavvful desire is accompanied also vvith the breach of the lavv;
• herby it appeareth that law in cōmanding or forbidding, help
•• h not sufficiently to the reformation of mans corrupt nature.

8. And can Permission or conniuence with euil (which is an
•• her point of the law) worke any greater effect? who seeth not •• at the same doth nothing else but bewray the imbecillity and 〈◊〉
•• perfection of law,Permission shevveth the imbecillity of lavv. seing it is forced to permit that which it •• adly would, and should remedy, but can not. And therfore I • il proceede to treate of Revvard, & Punishment, wherein as Solon
• as wont to say, principally consisteth the gouernment of commonwelth.
And Isidorus saith; Legis proemio aut poena vita m ••
ratur humana. Isidor. li. 50. Etimolog. Mans life is wholy gouerned, by the reward or p •
nishment of the lawe.

Of revvard and punishment.9. Now then for as much as these two haue al their oper ••
tion about the effectes of vertue or vice, that is to say about goo • or bad actions (which are only rewarded and punished by law) and not about the causes and rootes therof, to wit the good or bad habits or affections of the minde (from whence spring al good or euil actions) it is manifest, that though they may be motiues to good, yet they can not be effectual and sufficient meanes to worke it. For so longe as the cause remaineth, so long wil the effects followe therof at one time or other.

10. For as trees are yeerely cropped, and vines lopped, ye • whiles the rootes remaine sound, they bud a fresh, and bring forth new bowes, leaues and fruit; euen so, although euil & sinful acts be punished in wicked men, yet if the causes from whence they proceede (to wit the inordinate affections and passions) be not taken away, they produce the same effects sooner or later, openly or secretly. For what commonly followeth of the punishment of a vicious act, when the habit of the vi •• remaineth, but that the offendour sinneth more warily an othe • time? and how often doe men offend the lawes with our punishment, yea with out any feare or danger therof? That man (sait • Cicero) vvho feares nothing but a iudge and vvitnes, Cicero de leg. vvhat vvil be 〈◊〉 doe in the dark, or vvhen he finds a vveake and rich man alone, of vvho •• he may haue the spoyle?

11. Furthermore how many waies may the pennaltie of th • law be auoided? Some escape it by their power (in which respect Anacharsis compared lawes to the spiders webbe, whic • takes only the litle flees,Plut. in Solon. whiles the great-ones breake throug • it) and some againe auoid it by corruption either of the Iudge witnes,Hovv many vvayes the penaltyes of political lavves may be escaped. or iurie; and some by fauor and freendship, & other by negligence of officers, which doe not execute the lawes, an • some by the Princes pardon. But what shal we say of such as offend the law not only with out punishment, but also with reward? And to the end that this may the better appeare, and tha • with al we may see what force law may haue for the suppressiō of the malice of mans nature, let vs consider the force of a contrary
law, which euery commonwelth encountreth and im
• ugneth political law, to wit, the law of the flesh, whereof the • postle saith; Video aliam legem, &c. Rom. c. 7.
I see an other law in my body re
•• gnāt to the lavv of my mind. And for as much as this lawe hath al
• o her precepts, prohibitions, rewardes, and punishments,An exact comparison of political lavv, vvith the lavv of the flesh to shevv the aduantage of the later. let vs • ut it in ballance with the ciuil and political lawe, weighing the •• ne with the other, that we may see whether wil be like to ouer
• eygh in man voyd of Gods grace; and consequently in com
• onwelthes that relye only vpon humane policy and power.

12. It is therfore to be considered, that the carnal law flo
• inge from the very bottome of mans corrupt nature, is so • uch stronger, and more forcible then the other, to moue and • aw him, by how much it is more internal and familiar with • im, and the end or scope therof more agreable and consonant 〈◊〉 his corrupt humour, wil, and affection.VVherunto the political and carnal lavves do tend. For political law ten
• eth only to, Bonum verum, and bonum commune. A true good, and the •• mmon good, consisting in solid and perfect vertue; whereas the •• rnal law tendeth to, bonum apparens, and bonum priuatum. An appa
• at and priuat good, cōnsisting only in mans owne profit, pleasure, •• d delectation, wherto euery one is of his owne corrupt nature •• clined.

13. The like may be said also of the statutes and decrees of the • e and the other, that is to say, their precepts,The statutes of the political and carnal lavv. and prohibiti
• ns, consisting in commandments, negatiue, and affirmatiue, • herein the carnal law hath also the like aduantage, in respect 〈◊〉 the greater facility of the precepts therof, and the difficulty 〈◊〉 the thinges it forbiddeth. For wheras the ciuil and politycal •• w commandeth vs to loue our neighbours as our selues, and 〈◊〉 prefer the publike good before our priuate, to be temperate, •• d continent, not to steale, not to deceaue, not to commit for
•• cation, or adultery: the law of the flesh being opposite in al, • ommandeth the contrary, as to loue our selues better then our • eighbour, to prefer our priuate good before the publike, to • eale, and deceaue for our commodity, to commit fornication, •• d adultery for our pleasure, and to conclude al in one pre
•• pt it saith, Ede, bibe, lude, post mortem nulla voluptas. Eate, drink, and, 〈◊〉 merry, for after death ther is no pleasure.

14. These statutes of the carnal lawe the Holy Ghost layeth
downe notably in the booke of wisdome, speaking of wicke • men in these wordes: Dixerunt impij. &c. The wicked sayd, let 〈◊〉 enioy the goods that we haue,
Sap. 2. and vse the creature in this time of our yo •• without delay: let vs fil our selfe with wine and oyntements, and let vs 〈◊〉 loose the flovver of the time, &c. let vs leaue euery where the signes of 〈◊〉 mirth, for this is our part, and this is our lot; let vs oppresse the poore 〈◊〉 man, and let vs not spare widdovv, nor haue respect to the hoary hea ••• of any; and let our strength be the lavv of iniustice. Loe here the statut •• of the flesh, which how much more consonant and agreable the • are to mans corrupt nature, and how much more easy to be pe •
formed then the statutes and decrees of the political law, th •• commaund and forbid the contrary, I need not to declare.

15. For who knoweth not that to learne vice a man hath n •• need of any great wit,Mans promptnesse to learne euil. or of a Councellour, or of cōpulsion; wh • is so simple that hath not wit inough to be wicked? whereas t • be vertuous we need not only wit, and capacity, maisters an • teachers, but also lawes, stripes, prisons, gyues, and gibbets; an • yet (as Seneca saith) VVe may thinke vve profit vvel if vve be none of th • vvorst; Seneca ep. 75. so that he which is either left to his owne corrupt natur • or hath no other then humane helpe, is drowned in vice an • sinne,Ibid. before he come within a kenning of the port of vertue VVe are (saith Seneca) taken vp by the vvay, vve labour to come to vert •• being already entangled and intercepted by vice; And no maruaile, seeing men voyd of grace, (for of such I speake) haue nether sufficient armes to defend them selues, nor refuge where to sa •• them selues. For reason which is their only weapon, not bein • strengthned by grace, is so weake and brickle, that it breaket • at the first blowe, and morall vertue (wherein consisteth 〈◊〉 their hope & refuge) is so hard to be attained, that a man rece •
ueth many deadly woundes of his enemy, before he can arri •• where it is. Besides that, his danger is the greater, for that th •• war is so domestical, and intestine, that he is not secure fro • him selfe; for that he is to fight not only with the world and th • diuel, but also with his owne passions and affections, in so muc • that his greatest feare may be, lest he him selfe betray him self • and render him selfe prisoner to his enemyes.

16. Furthermore we see that our procliuity to vice, and o •• auersion from vertue is such, that as it sufficeth to flesh a do ••
only once vpon sheepe,vyce •• sely learned and vertue very hardly. to make him a sheepe-werryer as long • he liueth; euen so one only taste of vice is enough to make a • an vicious euer after; wheras many acts are required to the •• rtayning of the habit of any one vertue, and so timely is mans •• eendship with sensuality the mother of vice, and so late his • nowledge, and vse of reason which leadeth to vertue, that he • ath gone halfe the way to vice, before he knowe where vertue welleth: by meanes wherof he cōmonly groweth to be vicious • ery early, to wit, in his child-hood, and vertuous very late, if •• er he proue vertuous at al; for the way to vertue is longe and •• d of difficulties, but the way to al kind of vice is easy,Eccle. ca. 21. & as Salo
• on saith, Complanata lapidibus; euen, and wel paued, short, and • one in a trice; Haud procul illa habitant, breuis est via qua sit eundum. Hesiod.
• ice dwelleth nor far from vs, the way is short, and al in descent. • hereupon the Poët saith, facilis descensus auerni, Vergi. li 6. AEnead. the descent to •• el is very easy. Finally of these two wayes our Sauiour saith,
•• ta porta et spatiosa via est, &c. The way is broade & Math. c. 7.
spacious that leadeth 〈◊〉 perdition and many enter in therat; but the gate is straite, and the vvay is •• rovv which leadeth to life, and few men find it. Thus we see,The aduantage that the carnal lavv hath of the political lavv. how • reat aduantage the law of the flesh hath of the political law, in •• spect of the facility that men find to fulfil the precepts therof, • hich in some are nothing else but to be vicious.

17.The carnal lavv hath her Aduocates, Orators, Philsophers and teachers. But what, doth it want any thing wher with political law furnished, which it hath not also in high degree, to be able to • old this competence? hath not this carnal law, (trow you,) •• er Aduocates, Orators, Philosophers, and teachers, to publish •• d proclaime it, to plead it, to teach it? how say yow, by al the • ct of Epicurus? whose doctrine consisted principally in the pre
•• pts of this law, and impugning as much as he durst the ciuil •• d political law? In which respect al Epicurians were bannished •• t of many good commonwelthes of Greece as Plutark testifieth, •• d that worthely.The doctrin of Epicurus and his follovvers. For Epicurus hauing made a demand in cer
•• ine questions which he wrote, whether a wise man would not • e against the political lawe, if he might be sure to escape puni
• ment? answered freely therto; yes truly. And writing to Idome
•• us (one of his schollers) he admonished him seriously not to • biect him selfe to the lawes and opinions of men, whensoeuer • e might hope to auoid the penaltie of the lawes. And Metrodorus
a disciple & familiar frend of his writing to his brother,Metrodorus a disciple of Epicurus. forbad him to goe to the warrs, & to endanger him selfe for the publike good of Greece, aduising him to drinke good wine at home, and to treat him selfe wel, that his body might receaue al pleasure, and contentment:Idem in his treatise that a man can not liue merily in the sect of Epicurus. Philip. 3. concluding that the cheife and soueraigne good, consisteth in the bellie, and in the pleasures therof. This is the philosophy that belongeth to the law of the flesh, & experience sheweth what numbers of professors there are therof in euery commonwelth. Quorum Deus venter est (as the Apostle saith) whose bellies are their Gods. whose indeauors tend to nothing, but to their priuate pleasure and commodity, who employ their witts, studies and penns to nothing so much, as to publish and promulgate the carnal lawe, in ambrous and lasciuious bookes, wanton poems, and scurrilous and baudy ballads,Youth corrupted by lasciuious bookes and ballads. which abound euery where to the corruption of youth, and consequently to the preiudice of the commonweale, and to the great shame, in my fancy, of the magistrats that see it and suffer it.

18. Moreouer to the end we may see that this carnal law wil yeeld in nothing to the political, hath it not also commonwelthes wherin it gouerneth, and a prudence & pollicy appropriate vnto it?The cōmon-vvealths vvhere in the carnal lavv gouerneth. politike Princes and magistrats that practise it? yea and politike writters that teach and maintaine it? How say you by al Tyrannical states, where al is drawne to the pleasure or particuler benefit of the Prince? Are not the same ruled according to the precepts of this lawe? Doe the magistrats and gouernours therof practise any other policy but prudentiam carnis,
Rom. 8. as the Apostle calleth it, the prudence and vvisdome of the flesh? And Machiauel whose workes are so highly esteemed of many states-men at this day; doth he teach any other gouerment,Machiauel de principe. then that which proceedeth from the principles of this law, to wit from selfe loue and particuler interest?

19. And this were not much to be wondered at, if it had not also a Religion conforme to it selfe;The carnal lavv hath religion, doctors and preachers. with doctors and preachers to defend, preach, and teach it. For as political law hauing the help and assistance of true Religion, is more perfect, & worketh far greater effect in commonwelth, for the establishment and conseruation therof (as in the second parte of this Treatise shalbe made manifest) so also the carnal lawe beinge masked
with the vizard of some religion either true or false , is of farr greater force to ouerthrowe and destroy Commonwelth; and therfore it seeketh alwaies to haue either the apparance & shew of true religion (in which respect Machiauel teacheth his tyrant to be an hipocrite) or else it serueth it selfe of some new fangled and false religion;Machiauel de principe. which the Apostle signifieth when amongst opera carnis, the workes of the flesh, Gal. 5. he numbreth sects of heritikes.
